PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location in this planet earth.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill.

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX: IMPACT ON VEHICLE INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the answer he gave me on 15 April, when he said he would consider whether to make public his Department's estimate of the effect on the car industry of the proposed fringe benefits tax. In view of the mounting concern about possible job losses because of the tax-a concern which has been acknowledged by the Minister in his admittedly unsuccessful attempt to modify the tax-will he now make that information available? I also ask him to provide the Treasury calculations, reportedly now to be given to industry representatives, on the impact of the tax. Finally, does he agree that, if the tax proceeds as proposed, it will pose a real threat to the success of the Government's car plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will direct to the Treasurer that part of Senator Chaney's question which relates to Treasury figures on the impact and other effects of the proposed fringe benefits tax and see whether that information is to be made available. My understanding is that it has not been made available to the car industry. Insofar as the information from my own Department is concerned, I intend to treat that information in the same way as the Treasury decides to treat its information. I will provide an answer on that as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the general effect of the fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle plan, I have always felt that it would have some adverse effect, but there are a variety of factors which will adversely affect the production of motor vehicles in Australia in the calendar year 1986. Many of those have been referred to before in the course of Question Time. They include the effects of a pull forward in demand into 1985, which was a record year for the car industry; some cyclical effects in the industry; the effect of the introduction of unleaded petrol, which has increased the price of motor vehicles; and the effect of the devaluation, which has affected the price of motor vehicles. All those factors must be taken into account, and it is difficult to isolate the precise effect of the fringe benefits tax separate from those other imposts on the car industry.

Senator Chaney well knows that there has been a variety of public assessments of the effects of the fringe benefits tax. I think the more thoughtful of those has taken into account a variety of other factors; for example, the column by Chanticleer in today's Australian Financial Review refers to the estimates of a very respected organisation, Martec-independent consultants on the motor vehicle industry-which put some qualification on some of the wider claims which have been made. As I have said on a number of occasions, the precise effect of the fringe benefits tax on cars cannot be assessed, although added to other factors the effect is likely to be adverse when one looks at last year's record production in this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, relates to the grounding of the 80,000-tonne Indian bulk carrier on Frederick Reef last Saturday. Can the Minister give assurances that all possible efforts are being made to ensure the safety of the 57 crew on board and to minimise potential damage to the Great Barrier Reef?

—The Senate will be aware of the extensive media coverage of the grounding of the 80,000-tonne Indian bulk carrier the Jhansi Ki Rani on Frederick Reef last Saturday, 26 April. The reef is about 300 miles east of Mackay and 90 miles east of the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef. The vessel was on a voyage to Japan carrying about 74,000 tonnes of coal from Newcastle with a crew of 57 persons on board. The Minister for Transport has advised me that the situation has stabilised, with the vessel firmly on the reef, and that the Department of Transport navigational aid vessel Cape Moreton is anchored in the lagoon off the reef ready to assist as required. Besides the possible salvage of the vessel which is currently being considered by the owners and the agents, the Department of Transport is active in a number of areas. It is considering the safety of the persons on the vessel and is monitoring the marine pollution threat from the vessel, if any. Senator Colston will be pleased to know that so far no pollution has been reported which would indicate any difficulties with the Great Barrier Reef. In addition the master has been asked to make a report on the circumstances of the accident in accordance with section 268 of the Navigation Act. The Department has already appointed an officer to investigate the accident fully and to see that every precaution is taken to ensure the protection of life, human as well as marine.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of criticism from the Minister for Housing, Mr West, about the continued allowance of negative gearing on share transactions? Does the Minister believe that the Government is being inconsistent by banning negative gearing on property investments, allowing it for share dealings and now allowing it to continue in respect of farm losses?

—I would have thought that even the Opposition would understand by now, since the Treasurer has repeated it innumerable times, the essential difference between negative gearing on rental property and negative gearing in other areas. The tax laws as they previously existed were being blatantly abused on the property rental market through negative gearing and the turnover of property before a taxable income was yielded. We had this round robin of property transactions through not necessarily a related group but a number of individuals or groups of individuals under which property was passed from hand to hand, negatively geared, and in such a way that it did not ever produce taxable income. That is a very important qualitative difference from negative gearing for company takeovers-whatever merit or demerit that might have. The round robin which I mentioned is a technique which is familiar to many members of the Liberal Party who used round robins with the connivance of the--
—Will you name one?

—Would I name one of the Liberal Party tax dodgers? I can name half the Western Australian Liberal Party finance committee. There were Ron Woss, Denis Horgan, Syd Corser, Hughes and two or three others whose names escape me at the moment. However, in total half the Western Australian Liberal Party finance committee sent companies to the bottom of the harbour. One of the techniques that was popular among tax evaders in the 1970s was the use of round robins. They organised a round robin of cheques in collaboration with, one might say, compliant banking institutions.

—Because the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has overtly refused to answer a question I want to ask, I now ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister the following question: Will the Government establish a Federal royal commission into nazi war criminals in Australia as called for by the New South Wales Parliament? Does the Government concede that a royal commission is the only way to establish fact from fiction and protect innocent people who may have been maligned? Finally, does the Government agree that, if the information presented in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Nazis in Australia is in any way correct, the Australian intelligence community must be held accountable for and exposed for its alleged inaccurate and misleading security reports on those persons?
—I regret the allegation made against the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
—It is not an allegation. He said so this morning. He would not answer it. He said that it was for the Prime Minister to answer.

—Well, I regret the allegation and his response. The Government has been monitoring recent accusations concerning the entry of alleged war criminals into Australia. Inquiries into records which may hold relevant information are being conducted by a number of Commonwealth Government agencies and are continuing. It is my understanding that no material has so far been revealed which would indicate that there was some systematic or organised program permitting war criminals to enter this country, either with or without the concurrence of the governments of the day. In these circumstances, it is not believed that there is sufficient justification for a royal commission. The available records on certain named individuals will be reviewed to see whether there is any indication that screening and immigration procedures were not correctly observed. I assure Senator Chipp that the Government is keeping the situation under review having regard to the outcome of those present inquiries and to any further accusations which may be made. I just add that some of these allegations have been made before, including the allegation that a number of those concerned are prominent members of the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy whether he has seen the reported comments of the Liberal member for Franklin about the price of home heating oil? Is there any basis for the member's claim that if he had not drawn attention to the situation prices would not have fallen? Was Mr Goodluck's so-called pressure on the Government and the oil companies the sole reason for the price drop? What are the facts of this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Franklin, in a familiar burst of vulgar self-promotion that is endemic among Tasmanian members but not, of course, senators, has been claiming that as a direct result of writing to me about the price of home heating oil, the price of this product has been reduced. That claim has been spread about by the Bulletin, most of the Tasmanian Press and a good deal else as well. Let me set the matter quite straight. Action was taken by me to have this matter investigated long before Mr Goodluck raised the issue-in fact, as soon as I became aware, as I did after the matter was raised with me, not by anyone on the other side at all but by a number of my Labor colleagues including the honourable members for Canberra and Calare and Senators Coates and, I think, Tate in this chamber, that the price of kerosene and home heating oil was not following petroleum prices down.

ANSWER.PARA: So it was on 21 March, two weeks prior to Mr Goodluck's letter to me, that I requested that the matter be examined by my Department. It was on 3 April, four days prior to receipt of Mr Goodluck's letter, that I signed a letter to the Treasurer seeking formal consideration of this matter by the Prices Surveillance Authority. It will be recalled that on 17 April I answered a question from Senator Tate in which I provided details of the substantial reply I received on that day from the Treasurer on this matter indicating that while prices had now fallen in fact in the market-place, nonetheless the Treasurer did propose to raise the matter with the Prices Surveillance Authority. I can advise the Senate further that the Prices Surveillance Authority is currently in the middle of an examination of the price movements of these non-notifiable products and should be in a position to respond to the Treasurer accordingly.

Again, in relation to Mr Goodluck's claim that the Government was simply unaware that these products did not have maximum wholesale prices set for them by the PSA, the Government, of course, was perfectly well aware of that and in fact announced the decision as to what the PSA would be monitoring and recommending prices in relation to back in 1984. At the same time, arrangements were made, as I said in answer to Senator Tate, to ensure that continued information was given to the PSA so that prices could be monitored on an ongoing basis.

So while I certainly do listen to representations that are made and look at information that is given to me by honourable members and senators on both sides of the Parliament and I do respond seriously to them, after Mr Goodluck's grandstanding on this occasion I am afraid that I will be taking about as much notice of him in the future as I did when he dressed up in his chicken feathers a few weeks ago and started squawking cock-a-doodle-doo.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that in an open session of the Socialist International conference on southern Africa held last week, Chairman Willy Brandt praised the work of former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser on the Eminent Persons Group? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the committee's progress and when it is likely to report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of Mr Brandt's complimentary remarks about the Commonwealth's initiative and Mr Fraser's role in it. I am grateful to Senator Sibraa for raising this matter. As honourable senators will know, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Nassau issued a Commonwealth accord on southern Africa which called on the South African Government to dismantle the system of apartheid, determine the existing state of emergency, release immediately and unconditionally Nelson Mandela and all other people imprisoned or detained for their opposition to apartheid, establish political freedom, lift the bans on the African National Congress and other political parties and initiate dialogue with all groups with a view to establishing a non-racial representative government. Under that accord a Group of Eminent Persons was established to seek to facilitate the processes of dialogue. As the name suggests, the Group is not, nor is it intended to be, an intergovernmental committee. Australia's nominee to the Group is Malcolm Fraser, who also acts as joint chairman of it. Members of the Group, whose efforts, including those of Mr Fraser, have been characterised throughout by a great deal of energy and expertise, have now made two visits to South Africa and have met a wide range of Government Ministers and black leaders. They have been asked to report to Heads of Government by the end of June.

ANSWER.PARA: What is happening is as follows: The accord Heads of Government from Zambia, Australia, the Bahamas, Canada, India, the United Kingdom and Zimbabwe, or their representatives, will meet after June this year to consider the report of the EPG and to review the situation. The Government takes the view that Commonwealth governments, in agreeing to a broad range of measures to impress upon the South African Government the urgent necessity for change, have adopted the Australian proposal to set up the EPG. Australia believes that it is vital that dialogue and negotiation for change across the lines of colour, politics and religion be instituted in South Africa and that there must be a suspension of violence on all sides to enable dialogue to take place at the earliest opportunity. Mr Hawke's visit to Washington and London involved discussions of this Commonwealth initiative and its importance was, I am advised, reaffirmed during the conversations he had in those two places. Finally, I mention that the Government understands that a South African reaction to its earlier discussions with the Group in March of this year is in train and will be considered by the Group at its meeting in London on 30 April. For its part, the Australian Government sincerely hopes that the Group will continue with its valuable work within the terms of its CHOGM mandate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. A constituent of mine rang a well-known country newspaper to insert an advertisement for a married couple to work on the farm and was told that she could not use the phrase `married couple' as it was discriminatory. The only words allowed were `two persons'. My constituent then asked on whose authority the words `married couple, could not be used. The reply was `The Human Rights Commission'. Will the Minister please inform the Senate if marriage is no longer a lawful and honourable estate? Does this mean that there is no more freedom of the Press when reporters refer to married couples? Does this now mean that potential employers can no longer even advertise for the type of employees who are best suited to the job?

—The Sex Discrimination Act does make it an offence to advertise in a way that discriminates against potential employees on the ground of their marital status. However, the prohibition on discrimination in the Sex Discrimination Act is not absolute; the Act includes an exemption for situations where the employment relates to domestic duties and where accommodation provided with a job is essentially domestic accommodation with the employer. In those situations it is not an offence for an employer to advertise for a married couple. I notice, incidentally, that in the Press reports of this matter, which have been widespread, there is some suggestion that there was a difficulty about even asking for a couple, as distinct from a married couple. I cannot believe that there is any prohibition in the Sex Discrimination Act, as has been alleged, on advertising in terms that are open-ended in that particular way, but that is a matter that I am further checking up with the Attorney-General.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the economic recovery in Australia since 1983. I ask the Minister: Are all parts of Australia sharing uniformly in the recovery, and, if not, what actions need to be taken to spread economic growth to all States and regions of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire asked whether the benefits of the economic recovery were being spread uniformly across Australia. The answer to that is clearly no. Those benefits are not being spread uniformly. In particular, the benefits are not being received in Queensland because the economic recovery has not taken place in Queensland to near the same extent as it has in the other mainland States. Indeed, Queensland is dragging down the rest of Australia and it has been for a number of years.

ANSWER.PARA: Coincidentally, I happen to have with me a copy of a Press release put out about ten days ago, I think, by Senator Maguire. It draws attention to some more statistics which reveal the relatively poor condition of the Queensland economy in relation to the rest of the country. It shows that in Queensland there are more people receiving unemployment benefits than there are in Victoria, even though the labour force of Victoria is some 67 per cent larger than the labour force of Queensland. That disparity in the number of people receiving unemployment benefits cannot be attributed, as the Premier has attempted to attribute it, to young people flocking to loaf under the sun in Queensland because in the most recent 12-month period for which figures are available there was a net migration from Queensland of people in the prime 20 to 34 working age group.

When the Queensland Premier gave his last policy speech in 1983, only 14.8 per cent of the nation's jobless people lived in Queensland. That figure has now risen to an appalling 18.1 per cent, which is just another way of drawing attention to the fact that the performance of the Queensland economy relative to that of the rest of Australia in the last three years has been abysmal and that Queensland is dragging down the rest of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Minister will be acutely aware that our current inflation rate, as measured by the consumer price index, is running at 9.2 per cent as compared with less than 2 per cent for Japan and Germany. Does the Minister agree with the comments by the Treasurer that the inflation rate is going according to plan and has peaked? Is this an inverted J curve theory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not an expert on the J curve so I will not comment on the last part of the question. There are plenty of people who are experts. So far as the serious part of the question is concerned, the latest CPI result for the March quarter is somewhat disappointing and there are some special factors in it, including increased automobile prices, I might add, and a reduction in petrol discounting, which have had a particular effect on that figure. I have not seen the precise statement made by the Treasurer, but certainly the Government expects a considerably better inflation outcome in the June quarter and a steadily better inflation outcome from then on. The effects of the devaluation on the Australian inflation rate have been somewhat staggered in their impact. Some of those effects, I believe, will still be coming through in the June quarter but will be offset by other factors which will have a beneficial effect.

ANSWER.PARA: In the overall context of the question, of course, it is a very obvious point for an Opposition to make that the inflation rate is not good when compared with that of other countries enjoying at the moment record low inflation rates-countries such as Germany and Switzerland. Nonetheless, the inflation performance has not been bad and we expect it to be better in the forthcoming months. It is not the only factor, of course, which goes to the important issue of competitiveness. There are a range of other factors, including the exchange rate, which affect relative results and that is one factor only which the Government regards as important.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women whether she is aware of statements made by Senator Haines at the recent Women's Electoral Lobby National Agenda on Women Conference and on radio this morning. Will the Minister comment on the claim by Senator Haines that the Prime Minister is not committed to his Government's policies on improving the status of women and that Labor achievements in women's affairs are due more to the persistence of Senator Ryan? Can the Minister comment on the further remark that she has `no right to say that WEL's claim for improved child care, portable housing and increased welfare benefits for single mothers to bring them above the poverty line were not based on economic reality'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can do without backhand compliments of that kind from Senator Haines. If Senator Haines had been paying attention to the program of improving opportunities for women being carried out by the Hawke Government she, like everybody else, would be aware that that program has been supported personally as well as politically by the Prime Minister.
—But she did get a standing ovation, didn't she?

—No. The fact that a few Democrats were there behaving like superannuated cheer leaders certainly does not amount to a standing ovation. It is really unfortunate that somebody who has the nous to be elected to represent the people of South Australia in this place, if only on the Democrat ticket, should judge economic illiteracy, populism and grandstanding to be a better way to get improvements for women than reasoned, careful policy development. It is very disappointing that an honourable senator who professes an interest in women, latter day profession though it is, should attack a government in the uninformed and misleading way that Senator Haines chose to do. The areas she mentioned were child care, benefits for low income women and housing. Everybody in the Senate knows, for example, that $65m was spent on child care in the last year of the Fraser Government. This year, we will spend about $145m. Any honourable senator who can say in a public place that our Government has not supported the expansion of child care is behaving very irresponsibly.

ANSWER.PARA: Similarly, to talk about housing in a way that suggests that our Government has not supported increased housing for poor women is absolutely and deliberately misleading. Honourable senators will be aware that 192,500 people have already benefited from the first home owners scheme. Many women have benefited in their own right and many more women have benefited as part of a marriage. Increases in public housing in every State and Territory have been dramatic. All these things have come about because of the successful economic strategy of our Government. It is also grossly misleading, or very ignorant, to suggest that the only way of assisting women in poverty is to give benefits. We have increased benefits and associated payments for children in each Budget but as well we have done the greatest and most effective thing to assist women to get out of poverty by implementing our job creation program. We have created over half a million jobs since we came to office. More than half of those half a million jobs have gone to women. There is no better or more effective form of assistance for women who are living in poverty-as pensioners, or in some other poverty stricken circumstance-than to create employment for them.

In terms of access of women to the labour market, let us look at our Government's record in education. Since our period in office began, more young girls than boys have been completing their secondary education and, therefore, more will be getting the benefit of the greatly increased secondary allowances scheme which will assist them to conclude their secondary education. Of the extra 25,000 higher education places that have been created by our Government, almost half are going to women because of the increased participation of women in the higher education sector. If Senator Haines does not understand that improved education at both the secondary and the tertiary level is the best way to ensure that women will have access to secure income, it is time she went back to the drawing board-started from scratch-and really informed herself about who in this country lives in poverty and who has secure income.

Our Government has consistently adopted constructive programs which give women the opportunity to get employment and employment skills and, at the same time, to have secure housing and affordable child care. That a senator who has been in this place long enough to know all these things should go into a public forum and on the media and shamelessly deny all these facts is, I think, a disgrace to her and to her Party. As far as advocacy for women is concerned, it is absolutely pathetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Resources and Energy acknowledge that, within primary industry, hop producers heating kilns with liquefied petroleum gas are now facing a severe cost disadvantage compared with those using diesel? Will the Minister review this position with a view to alleviating it by reducing government levies to primary producers using LPG in farming operations?

—The question as to the pricing and taxation policy in relation to petroleum products is before the Industries Assistance Commission at the moment. That is one issue that will, no doubt, be addressed in that context. It will certainly be looked at further by the Commonwealth. I will say only this about LPG pricing: The great difficulty with that over recent years has been the extraordinary volatility of price movements in that commodity. A deliberate decision was taken some time ago by this Government to introduce a system of consumer price index related price movements and international price related movements in LPG which would take out that volatility, seasonal and otherwise, and give users-in particular local government users and so on, for whom this was important-some certainty. As to automotive LPG and the pricing policy in relation to that, and the possible--
—Heating fuel specifically for kilns.
—The honourable senator is talking about heating fuel?
—Yes.

—I thought that was the case. I will look at the matter further in the light of Senator Watson's question. It is a policy that was deliberately established, I think a couple of years ago, in order to give certainty at the expense of volatility. For that reason we have stuck with it, even though the recent price movements in LPG have in fact been counter to the trend for petroleum products generally, flowing from the decline in crude oil prices. I will have another look at the question and give Senator Watson a more considered answer if it seems appropriate to do so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORFOLK ISLAND: VISIT OF LA DIEPPOISE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Territories aware of a recent visit to Norfolk Island by a French patrol boat, La Dieppoise? Was this visit an attempt by the French to repair relations with the Norfolk Island authorities in the aftermath of the sinking of the Greenpeace vessel the Rainbow Warrior? Did the visit have the desired effect?

—I am advised that there was a goodwill visit to Norfolk Island by the French patrol boat La Dieppoise on 17 April. The purpose of that visit was ostensibly to establish good relations between our two countries. However, I am advised that it appears that during the visit the French Consul-General, who was making a visit to the island simultaneously with the patrol boat, was questioned by police regarding allegations of offensive behaviour while on the beach at Emily Bay. The allegation is that in a public place-the beach at Emily Bay-he engaged in such conduct that is normally carried out privately. I do not sit in judgment upon such behaviour, but it was brought to the attention of the authorities and he was questioned by the police regarding his activities while there. The Consul-General apologised and left Norfolk Island at the completion of his visit. I suppose this could be said to be an example of French diplomacy at work. No wonder the French seem to be in some trouble in the Pacific area, having regard to what happened in New Zealand, now at Norfolk Island and, of course, the French testing at Mururoa Atoll. It would appear that this is probably a minor explosion compared with the other difficulties the French Government found itself in.

—Will the Minister for Resources and Energy give all available details of the nuclear reactor accident in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, reported today? In view of the spread of radioactivity to Scandinavian countries, does this not substantiate the view that nuclear accidents cannot be contained or prevented and represent an international threat? In view of the increasing frequency and seriousness of nuclear accidents, will the Government withdraw its support for uranium mining and instead carry out its moral obligations to protect human life and the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As of an hour ago, when I last checked, the Government did not have any details additional to those already released through the media today in relation to the nuclear power reactor accident at the Chernobyl site in the USSR. Further information on this is being sought through Australian representatives in the USSR and the Scandinavian countries affected by this accident. I will certainly put further information before the Senate if and when it becomes available.

ANSWER.PARA: As to some of the other questions Senator Sanders has put to me, while no method of power generation is risk free, the nuclear record to date, notwithstanding this apparent accident, has been excellent. In the 3,600 reactor years of operating experience there have been very few significant accidents. Whilst it is not possible to confine radiation once released, this is also true of pollutants released from other forms of power generation. In the case of nuclear powered generation, in Western countries reactors are encased in a containment building specifically engineered to prevent releases of radioactivity to the atmosphere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for the cracks in them.

—That may be, but it is that that I think is well appreciated as one of the reasons why there was no dangerous release of radioactivity in the context of the Three Mile Island accident. Some Russian reactors, however, do not have containment buildings. We are not certain yet whether it is the case that the Chernobyl reactors are in that category. That is one of the things on which we are seeking further advice, because that will very much determine one's estimate of the size of the accident in this case. It is not possible, without knowing the answer to that particular question, to say whether there are any implications for Western reactor installations.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the other parts of the question, Australia does not sell uranium to the USSR. The absence of mining in this country would not have prevented the present accident. As to moral obligations about which Senator Sanders asked me, the Australian Government's view is that it has a moral obligation to continue to provide uranium to those countries which lack adequate energy resources and which rely on nuclear power for a substantial proportion of their energy needs, provided they have concluded agreements obliging them to observe the strict safeguards that are imposed on all Australian uranium exports. I make the further point that we have, I believe, not only a moral obligation but also a legal obligation to so act by virtue of our status as a signatory and an active proponent of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which combines an obligation not to participate in any way in the proliferation of nuclear weapons with an equally compelling obligation to make available nuclear technology and nuclear power sources-uranium-for peaceful purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a former distinguished senator for South Australia, Mr Jim Toohey, and Mrs Toohey. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend to them a warm and friendly welcome upon their return to Canberra.

—I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is it true that Queensland coal companies are facing an unfair burden of State rail freight and port charges which is restricting their competitiveness? How can the Queensland Government claim that Queensland is a low tax State when it is reaping freight and royalty profits from the coal industry of up to $600m a year? What impact do such State charges have on Australia's overseas trading prospects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland Government is understandably reticent about the so-called profit element embodied in its rail freights or port charges. The rail freight agreements negotiated between the Queensland Government and the coal producers are confidential and that inhibits, I regret, informed debate on the matter. However, the Queensland Chamber of Mines has stated that it has estimated that the total income from the coal rail freight tax totalled $364m in 1984-85. I should make it clear that the Commonwealth Government is not opposed to the concept of taxation of resource industry revenues. However, as I stated last week to the Australian Coal Conference in Queensland, Commonwealth and State taxes and charges on the coal industry, of which rail freights are pre-eminent, need to be reviewed and, I believe, replaced with a more equitable and rational taxation scheme. Taxation arrangements which are open to the public view and which do not discourage production at the margin-which arguably the present rail freight regime, particularly in Queensland, certainly does-are surely better than a concealed system of taxation.

ANSWER.PARA: It has not been easy in recent years to have any kind of rational dialogue with the Queensland Government, although it has not been unique among the States in respect of taxation matters, on questions of resources taxation. The present rather stressed condition of a whole variety of resource industries makes it imperative that a sensible, constructive and co-operative approach be taken to these questions of taxation. I look forward-although it will be difficult in an election year-to some appropriately constructive response in due course from the Queensland Government and not the kind of rather ill thought-out reactions we have had so far on this very important question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Did he see reports in the media last week that a campaign is being organised by certain trade unions, led by Mr Tom Ryan of the notorious Food Preservers Union, to prevent the introduction of a system of food irradiation in Australia? Is this campaign being aided and abetted by the honourable members for Capricornia and Hindmarsh on behalf of the Australian Labor Party? Does the Minister accept that the irradiation of food, if carried out in accordance with standards and practices such as those being developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, is perfectly safe, prolongs the shelf life of food, and helps avoid very significant losses to growers and food producers? Will the Minister give assurances that a sensible approach to food preservation problems will not be sidetracked by ill-informed campaigns mounted by left wing unions and their parliamentary mouthpieces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I will ignore that last remark, except to suggest that anyone who describes Mr Keith Wright as Mr Tom Ryan's mouthpiece in this Parliament must have a very strange view of the ideological and philosphical positions of people in the Australian Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: I did notice the article in the Australian, I think it was, concerning the views of Mr Tom Ryan and others on the irradiation of food. I did not see the article anywhere else and it did not seem to create much excitement around the place. The Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council has developed a model food standard for food irradiation and I understand that this model will be on the Council's agenda at its next meeting. The model is based on the international standard developed and endorsed by the Codex Alimentarious Committee of the World Health Organisation and the Food and Agriculture Organisation. The model has been developed after considerable consultation with the scientific community, with the State and Territory Departments of Health, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, representatives of the food industry, and relevant unions.

The Department of Health is developing an information paper on the irradiation of food-stuffs, and that paper, it is expected, will form the basis of discussion by consumers and interested parties throughout Australia. It is important that we do have proper discussion on this. When we do have discussion on this, it is expected that people who have either direct interests or concerns as to the effects of irradiation on food, or who have indirect concerns as to the effect on employment of irradiated food being made available-I suspect that this is what Mr Ryan is concerned about-will have their say. If Senator Puplick wants to say that conducting a campaign against irradiation is having one's say, he can. But I do not think that is very effective.

The decision about the model will be made by the NHMRC and the Government. The future of irradiation as a means of preserving food in this country will be made by the Federal and State departments of health as a result of consultations and discussions with experts and with the community at large. The reason that some countries have banned irradiation as a means of preserving food has frequently not been to do with irradiation per se, but to do with such things as employment and the protection of their own industries. I dare say that all those factors will also be taken into account in Australia. I will let the honourable member for Capricornia and the honourable member for Hindmarsh, who are allegedly the mouth-pieces for Tom Ryan, know that they have been described as such. I will let them answer that accusation in their own way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has his attention been drawn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics' publication Government Financial Estimates 1985-86, released on 22 April this year, which shows that the deficit of the Commonwealth Government Budget sector dropped from $6.6 billion in 1984-85 to an estimated $4.8 billion in 1985-86, which represents a decrease of 27 per cent? Is he also aware that in Queensland the State Government Budget sector deficit rose from $541m in 1984-85 to an estimated $1.2 billion in 1985-86, a rise of 113 per cent? Does this mean that the estimated deficit in the Queensland Budget sector is the highest of any Australian State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The publication Government Financial Estimates 1985-86 was issued on 22 April and I note that it has the name of the former Secretary to the Department of Finance on the first page as the Australian Statistician. Senator Jones referred in the question to the decline in the Commonwealth Budget deficit. Those figures, as I recall them, are correct. He also referred to the relative indebtedness of Queensland compared with other States. I think probably a more reliable indicator of the rate of increase in indebtedness in a State is the total State deficit rather than the Budget sector deficit. This is particularly so, I think, in the case of Queensland. The Queensland Government has adopted, to a greater extent than other governments have, the practice of heavy borrowings through statutory authorities which are not recorded as budget sector deficits, but which are still, of course, public sector deficits and ultimately a liability charged against the citizens and taxpayers of Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the total State deficit on a per capita basis. This, of course, is the most reliable way or, indeed, the only realistic way of making such comparisons when there are enormous variations in population between the smaller State of Tasmania and the largest State of New South Wales and, therefore, huge variations in the absolute amount of public sector debt incurred. Looking at that on a per capita basis we see that it is certainly true that Queensland's increase in public sector indebtedness in 1985-86 is by far the highest of any mainland State. Indeed, at $67 per capita it is more than double the New South Wales figure of $33, some 50 per cent higher than the Victorian figure of $46, almost double the South Australian figure of $36 and some 25 or 30 per cent higher than the Western Australian figure of $53. I have not yet mentioned Tasmania, the only State which on a per capita basis had a higher increase in public sector debt than the State of Queensland. As I recall, this is not new. Queensland has been going down that road for a considerable number of years. It has a very rapidly increasing level of public sector debt, even to the point, I would suggest, of being dangerous. As I have said many times before, Queensland has an abysmal economic performance accompanying that very rapid and alarming increase in public sector debt.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAPITAL GAINS TAXES AND DEATH DUTIES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that the Minister for Primary Industry told the National Farmers and Graziers Association meeting at Horsham on 23 October 1984 that he would oppose any new capital gains taxes and death duties in the strongest terms? I ask the Minister also whether he is aware that Mr Kerin was reported in the Australian newspaper on 9 April as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: My objection to a capital gains tax is the same as probate in that it has the effect of rendering the rural sector in the long term less viable. The family has to sell part of the property to pay probate or capital gains tax.

If this is so, why is the Minister now saying that the capital gains tax is in the farmers' long term interest? Is this Government policy? Would the Minister not agree that the Minister for Primary Industry has been telling rural Australians, farmers in particular, complete untruths?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all let me say that the integrity and honesty of the Minister for Primary Industry is something which shines out like a beacon in the history of Primary Industry Ministers in Australia. Part of the problem of the rural sector of the Australian economy is that it has been pulled by the nose for too long by National Party representatives in this place and cluttered with a whole range of subsidies which it saw as the solution to its problems. I suggest that if the honourable senator does not know that she should look at the video of the meeting late last year between a selected group from the National Farmers Federation, Minister Kerin and Mr Ian Sinclair, to see what that group's view was on that occasion about the sort of policies which have got farmers into their present difficulties. The policies that have got them into their present difficulties have been the policies of poujadism and agrarian socialism adopted by the National Party over many years rather than confronting the real issues that face the Australian rural sector.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no idea what Mr Kerin said at Horsham on 23 November 1984. However, I do not regard it as being in the slightest degree relevant because what the honourable senator later suggested was that the report in the Australian newspaper quoted him as having drawn some correlation between a capital gains tax and probate duties. I suggest that the honourable senator read her own question again. There is no question of probate duties, so she can stop pursuing that straw man in Queensland in the course of the forthcoming election campaign. I would not bother about that if I were her, because there is no question of probate duties. In respect of the very significant exemptions from the proposed capital gains tax, if anybody benefits it will of course be the rural producer. That was structured in such a way as to ensure that precise effect. To suggest, on the basis of a couple of miscellaneous Press quotations or alleged comments made by the Minister last year, culled no doubt by a diligent but not very intelligent research assistant--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was me.

—That was the honourable senator? I am sorry-I thought the honourable senator had put her imprimatur on the work of some research assistant. I did not imagine that she had done it herself. I apologise for any suggestion which I made. To throw those two things together for the purpose of trying to denigrate one of the best Ministers for Primary Industry this country has ever had is a shabby little exercise.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to criticism made by the Opposition spokesman for transport of the adequacy of the Australian design rule system, particularly with respect to the problem of failing seat adjusters on Chrysler Valiant vehicles? If so, is he able to comment on the criticism and can he inform the Senate of any action taken by the Government?

—There is a conflict of opinion between the Federal Office of Road Safety and Mitsubishi, which is responsible for Chrysler vehicles, arising out of some experiences in respect of Valiant seat adjusters used in Chrysler vehicles. I have seen the criticism that has been made and that criticism is generally correct. The problem is exacerbated by the failure of the company to recognise that a defect exists. Numerous cases have been reported of seats breaking free of their mountings at a lower level of impact than is required by design rules put out by the Federal Office of Road Safety. Subsequent tests conducted by the Federal organisation have shown that seat slides in Chrysler vehicles are defective. However, the Government is in difficulty because Mitsubishi has refused to accept the fact that there are defects and has refused to recall vehicles as requested. The technical advice that is available to the Federal Government as well as to State governments indicates that the State governments ultimately have the power to refuse registration for non-compliance with Federal road safety regulations. The difficulty is that, regardless of the dispute as to whether there is a defect, there is little, if any, evidence to show that injuries have been sustained. It is on that basis that Mitsubishi has rejected the proposals by the Federal Office of Road Safety. There is, therefore, a clear deficiency in the legislation which points to a weakness in the voluntary code of recall. Consequently, the Government is considering amending the Trade Practices Act to backup the voluntary codes where we are not able to reach agreement with the company involved in respect of road safety matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

I have some further information as follows: Senator Kilgariff will by now, I believe, have received a letter from Mr Gutman indicating that he has already in fact visited Darwin and Pine Creek and is proposing to visit Tennant Creek in May. As to the question of the public hearing in the Northern Territory, I have been advised by Mr Gutman, through the Treasurer's office, as follows:

DEBATE.TITLE: CHANGES TO EXPORT INSPECTION MINISTERIAL ORDERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement on changes to export inspection ministerial orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Amendments to the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders made under the Export Control Act 1982 entered into force on 18 February 1986, and were not disallowed by the House of Representatives within the statutory time limit. They have however run into trouble in the Senate, with the threat of a disallowance vote to be taken here on 30 April 1986.

Senators would be well aware that these orders were introduced as a result of a recent Full Federal Court bench decision which found that the law did not give effect to the Government's intentions in regard to one aspect of the provision of a cost effective export inspection service by the Department of Primary Industry.

The amendments gave the Department of Primary Industry the legal right to take into account issues affecting management efficiency, staff safety, and welfare of relevant export industries when considering requests to provide services; and also gave the Minister for Primary Industry the right to intervene in departmental decision making processes where it is in the national interest to do so. They also provide for decisions by officials to be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

If the amendments were not made, the orders would have required the Department to provide inspection services unless `impossible' to do so, regardless of the consequences to Australia, the cost, or any consideration of staff welfare and safety. The Minister would have had no clearly defined right to become involved, even though he is answerable to this Parliament for the actions of his Department.
The provisions break no new ground in either administrative law or delegated legislation. Similar provisions are contained in many pieces of legislation passed by this and previous parliaments.

The amendments were considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and specialised legal advice was received by that Committee. As senators would be aware, the Committee is a bi-partisan committee comprised of members of the major political parties which examines all delegated legislation to ascertain whether the legislation satisfies the following four principles:
(A) That it is in accordance with the statute;
(B) that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;

(C) that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of the citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal; and
(D) that it does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

The Chairman of the Committee told the Senate on 19 March 1986 that after considering the orders generally and the legal adviser's report in particular, the Committee concluded that it could not object to the orders under its principles and that the Committee did not consider that any of its principles were infringed.

In this particular issue there has been too much concentration on the political aspects of the Mudginberri Abattoir dispute and the subsequent legal proceedings and not enough on the problems that the amendments to the legislation are designed to overcome. The amendments were not made to allow the Government to avoid its responsibilities or to give the unions more power. They are in the interest of proper government administration and are to correct what is widely acknowledged to be a deficiency in existing legislation.

However, for political reasons the Opposition parties chose to oppose the changes in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. I say for political reasons because while their record of public administration leaves much to be desired, I cannot believe that their grasp of the principles of proper administration is so poor as for them to oppose the changes on any other grounds.

The House of Representatives passed the changes but the Opposition parties in the Senate threatened to disallow the orders. As a consequence the Senate was asked for time to refer the matter to the industry for further consideration, as the Minister believed that the meat industry, in particular, needed more time to consider the issue. He was given until 30 April.

Because of the importance to the meat industry, the Minister arranged for the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council (AMLIPC) to look at the issue. The Chairman of the Inspection Policy Council has also provided him with a view.

Indications from the first meeting of the AMLIPC held to discuss the issue were that they felt the orders as proposed were too broad. As a result senior officials from the Department discussed the matter with the AMLIPC and put before the Council for consideration revised wording of the orders to make the conditions of the discretion more specific.

The Minister believes that the reworded orders adequately address industry's concerns and consequently the Government is willing to compromise and make changes to the orders put before the Senate in an effort to find common ground.
In framing these amendments the Government has considered the need of Australia's meat and livestock industry to develop and maintain a reputation as a reliable supplier on the international market.

However, AMLIPC was only able to agree unanimously that provision should be made for withholding inspection services where staff are not available to satisfy all applications within applicable budgetary limits and where there is an occupational health or safety risk.

The majority of AMLIPC members were not supportive of the other provisions, namely that inspection services might be temporarily withheld where there is a risk of physical assault or intimidation of staff, even where the police are agreed that there is a risk, or where there is a need for a `cooling-off' period in the event of an industrial dispute-although they did offer to have the industry further consider the industrial relations aspects at a later date.

The AMLIPC also opposed any provision which would give the Minister a right to intervene in departmental decision making when the national interest is involved. The previous views expressed by the Opposition parties in the House of Representatives and in the Senate on ministerial involvement are difficult to fathom. National interest in this context covers the interests of the industry and the public interest and it is clear that there may be times when the public interest is greater than that of the industry and this must at least be able to be taken into account without recourse to the courts.

The unclear position of the responsible Minister's involvement in officials' decisions where national interest considerations may be involved runs contrary to all the principles of our system of elected government.

The attitude by some industry groups and by the Opposition to the realities of managing a complex service industry seems blinkered, possibly because the issue is still being clouded by the emotionalism attached to Mudginberri and by political considerations of the organisations concerned.

Quite frankly it is beyond me how anyone can refuse to agree to clarify the law where staff safety is involved or where some cooling-off period for industrial negotiation is desirable. On the question of staff safety, the inspection service has on a number of occasions been confronted with staff being placed at physical risk by threats of violence or actual violence. In a very recent incident such threats led to an inspector being physically assaulted and injured off the premises. The service must not be put in a position where there are any doubts about its legal right to clear its staff from such situations.

Further it should be recognised that most industrial disputes involving inspection staff are localised and short in duration being resolved by level-headed conciliatory negotiation. To inflame such minor disputes by immediately trying to force inspectors to work regardless of the circumstances and merits of the case is stupid in industrial relations terms. We must allow management the flexibility to have a short `cooling-off' period to negotiate and attempt a conciliation.

We have a recipe for industrial disaster if the orders are not amended. Those opposed to the amendments are, in fact, putting more power in the hands of the unions, for the unions are now the only group that has any discretion.

Recognising the importance of these issues, the Inspection Policy Council (IPC) while not being unanimous on the matter is in general agreement with the inclusion of provisions which would allow services to be withheld where availability and management efficiency are involved and in the interests of staff-safety and to provide an industrial relations `cooling-off' period. The proposal to allow ministerial intervention is also generally supported by IPC on the grounds that it will effectively provide an additional avenue for appeal. I would point out that the IPC has indicated to the Minister previously their unanimous view that it is untenable to have the inspection service and the Government placed in the position where they have little say in the provision of an inspection service, yet are held fully accountable for that service.

Following receipt of this advice from the AMLIPC and IPC, the Minister has had new orders prepared. The new orders which were gazetted and tabled in the House of Representatives and in the Senate today are explained in the explanatory statement. Briefly, they repeal the existing provisions and substitute more detailed criteria under which a discretion may be exercised. The criteria are drafted so as to leave some scope for negotiations to take place in an industrial dispute and to give flexibility where there is physical threat to staff. In the ministerial directions provision, the Minister would be required to consult directly with relevant industry bodies before making any direction on `national interest' grounds.

The Senate should note that industry supports orders 100a and 100b. While the new orders 100a and 100b go some way to resolving the administrative problems, industrial, staff safety and public accountability aspects are not, however, recognised. What the industry is doing is asking the management of the inspection service to run its operation in a commercial way without the discretion that they themselves demand in their own daily businesses.

I notice from the Hansard of the Senate debate of 19 March 1986, that there was some concern expressed that ministerial direction should be provided for in the principal Act, rather than orders. I gather this was despite the view of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I hope that commonsense now prevails in the Senate. The orders as now presented represent a genuine attempt by this Government to meet the requests of industry. They reflect the Minister's concern that disallowance would result, over time, in greater costs and detract from the ongoing drive to provide inspection services in an efficient and cost effective way in accordance with the accepted principles of good public administration.

The judgment of the Full Bench is very clear on the point that under the previous law the inspection service must provide services unless it is actually impossible to do so. The Full Bench clearly indicated that the policy aspects could be fixed by amending the orders, and the Government has taken this course of action. If any of the new orders are disallowed then the Minister would wish to make it clear that the inspection service will abide by the law, in a sensible, non-emotional way-but it will not, as some people seem to think, disregard the law when it suits the industry for it to do so.

DEBATE.TITLE: ACCESS AND EQUITY IN THE DELIVERY OF FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SERVICES AND PROGRAMS TO MIGRANTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Text of Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) on Access and Equity in the Delivery of Federal Government Services and Programs to Migrants is a most important document. The Government clearly believes that migrants, particularly those of non-English speaking background, should not have their right to access to and participation in government services restricted simply by language difficulties. Many of these restrictions are for services which the English speaking community take for granted as part of everyday life. The ethnic communities of Australia have been calling for Federal Government action and have been successful in raising awareness and implementing programs in some of the State governments. Clearly, a Federal overview of its services and access to those services is paramount. It is not good enough for the Government to take a paternalistic view of what migrants need or should have for their own good. Access means participation in decision-making. On page 5 of this report the Minister concedes that:
. . . in the delivery of services and implementation of programs, much remains to be done.

This is an understatement. The second part of the document entitled `Overview of action taken and required to implement policy' is a litany of the appalling mess which now exists. In data collection, Federal Government departmental statements on services and access to services have revealed that there is not much. Without this information, how can the Government assess the participation of migrants in programs and their use of services? The provision of information in community languages is, in the Minister's words, `somewhat variable'. Further on he states:
One matter that is conspicuously absent from most statements is any evidence of Departments or Agencies actively seeking information about problems regarding access and equity.

Clearly, some government statements reflect departments' lack of understanding of the issues involved and the Government's policies on access and equity. There is a great deal to be done in educating some of the Ministers and, indeed, a large number of their officers.

Finally, I am concerned that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs believes, firstly, that the Government has reason to be pleased with its achievements in access and equity in the delivery of services and programs to migrants, and, secondly, that it has been able to achieve this within the existing financial constraints. The reality is revealed in the Ombudsman's progress report of 1983-84, where he advises that budgetary constraints have seriously limited staffing resources available to undertake publicity, to produce information, or to monitor the effectiveness of such publicity within ethnic communities. In Australia today we are past seeing the Anglo-Celtic section of the community as representing the whole of this nation. The whole nation is the sum total of all the varied parts which go to make it so rich. To then say that we are achieving much for this nation within budgetary constraints is to get one's priorities around the wrong way. The very basis of justice in our society is offended if any part of that society does not have access and equity in the delivery of Federal Government services and programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, like the Australian Democrats, is very concerned at the report on Access and Equity in the Delivery of Federal Government Services and Programs to Migrants and the statement brought down by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). There is an apparent disregard, or even apathy, in the case of many departments as to the need to deliver services for immigrants and for those in ethnic communities. The paper seems to represent some kind of apologia for the mistakes or omissions of the Government over many years and seems to be an attempt to try to put the matter into some kind of better light as a result of the Government's analysis of it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have particular concerns at the lack of progress in the delivery of services to those of non-English speaking backgrounds, particularly in the area of interpretation in legal cases and certainly in the provision of information in the language of those ethnic groups which are using the services of the Department of Social Security and other service departments. The lack of staff training in some of these departments and the lack of attention being paid to the vital elements of taking a little extra care and a little extra time to deal with people who have language difficulties is certainly the essence of what the Opposition is seeking to see happen in this area. Unfortunately, the Government's statement does not give us that confidence that it has all these matters firmly in hand.

As I mentioned earlier, it is something of an apologia. I suppose it is timely, from the point of view of the Government's political imperatives, to bring down such a statement without necessarily addressing more totally the problems faced by those who are not able to address themselves fully in the English language. The statement does represent some progress, however, by drawing our attention to the shortcomings that do exist. It is for that reason and to that degree, I suppose, that we should be pleased that it is made available to all. The point now needs to be made that the Government must continue to monitor the situation and to improve its performance in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Messner in relation to the Opposition's response to the report on Access and Equity in the Delivery of Federal Government Services and Programs to Migrants and the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). There are some aspects of the report, of course, that are valuable and useful. I certainly have no opposition to those aspects, but what does concern me-I think it is the point on which Senator Messner concluded his comments-is that really what the report is all about is the question of access by some disadvantaged groups in the ethnic communities to government services. The report covers the question of bureau enforcement of various provisions, the establishment of numerous special bodies to engage in yet more research, training programs, and all that sort of material, but nowhere does it deal with the basic problems and issues that migrants and ethnic communities in Australia, along with many other Australians, face in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, for example, questions such as adequate housing, adequate employment-particularly jobs for our young people-and education for employment rather than, to quote from the report, `having warm relationships with teachers'. Certainly those things are important, but surely the more important things are the essence aspects that the report does not address. A classic example of that in relation to the Government's activities in these and related areas at the moment is the area of housing. We have recently had a ministerial statement and a decision by the Government to increase the migration intake into Australia over the period ahead-a decision I welcome-but in conjunction with that there has been a decision by the Government to take action in the taxation area in relation to negative gearing to increase greatly the cost of rental accommodation and to reduce the availability of rental accommodation. We have another example of a basic conflict and contradiction between two areas of government policy-taxation-housing policy on the one hand and migration policy on the other hand. One matter which concerns this side of the Senate and this side of politics is the increasing number of examples of basic contradictions that occur day after day between government policies. There is no evidence of an attempt to co-ordinate government policy in the interests of those community groups, and the community at large, about which the Government professes to be concerned. Whilst not being highly critical of this report, I believe it fails to address the real issues. I commend the report entitled `Australia's Plant Breeding Needs' by Professor Lazenby. However, it is somewhat unfortunate that this report was not accompanied by a government paper of support. The Government lost a great opportunity by not including a plant variety package within its recent economic statement to the Parliament outlining a series of measures which were designed to help the rural industry. This omission is unfortunate for a number of reasons. The Government cannot claim that it did not have the report in sufficient time to include recommendations in the package because the report was presented to the Government in February 1986. Therefore, I now call upon the Government to support Professor Lazenby publicly in his recommendations to implement a plant variety scheme at the earliest opportunity. The report is quite unequivocal in its support for plant variety rights.

It is particularly important for my State of Tasmania, which has a very high dependence on horticultural industry. Professor Lazenby says that, on balance, the benefits for Australia stemming from a plant variety scheme are likely to outweigh considerably any adverse effects.

The report goes on to state that it was neither desirable nor logical for Australia to stand aside from the mainstream of developed nations in the hope of providing some intangible benefits to Third World countries. The benefits of a PVR scheme are enormous. They include increased resources directed to plant breeding, better use of germ plasm, improved access to varieties which are bred overseas, better use of public plant breeding resources and improved integration of breeding with basic research and new developments in technology. It is vital that there also be a strong public plant breeding activity, that that activity be maintained and that it be guaranteed long term funding, because one of the characteristics of any plant breeding scheme is its very high cost and the long term nature of its programs. I think it is unfortunate that-the report acknowledges this-there is some evidence of declining State government support. But the universities, departments of agriculture and primary industry have a legitimate and continuing role in plant improvement programs, including the right to develop finished varieties.

I think it is important that there be a strong public breeding program. It is also significant that this view is endorsed by the majority of breeders, who believe that royalties paid on public varieties should be returned for crop improvement programs. Such action would offer a real opportunity for providing tangible incentives for the public breeder. I think the following, which I quote from the report, is also important:
. . . the relationship between the public and private sectors should be evenhanded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.
