DEBATE.TITLE: NAVIGATION AMENDMENT (DEREGULATION OF COASTING TRADE) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hamer) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to repeal Part VI of the Navigation Act 1912, so as to remove the obligation for ships to obtain a licence or a permit to engage in coasting trade, and to repeal other sections of that Act which relate only to the coasting trade.
Bill presented by Senator Hamer, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes to repeal Part VI of the Navigation Act.

Part VI comprises a set of rules which apply separately to interstate shipping, making coastal shipping separate and distinct from overseas shipping. Under this part of the Act, interstate trade can only be undertaken by ships registered in Australia or by a foreign ship operating with similar crew numbers and similar crew conditions to those applying to Australian ships.

The only situation in which a foreign ship may obtain a permit to operate in the coasting trade without meeting the stringent Australian crew requirements is for a single voyage where no suitable Australian ship is available for that particular freight movement.

To ensure that only Australian ships or foreign ships meeting the Australian crew requirements operate in the coasting trade, a licence or permit is issued for ships to operate this trade and no ship can operate in the coasting trade without this licence or permit.

This Navigation Amendment Bill will repeal the onerous and iniquitous requirement for a licence to operate in the interstate trade of Australia. For what this Part VI has achieved is a monopoly over the coasting trade, a rort for the seagoing unions in Australia and a high cost service for which all Australians have been paying dearly for since 1921.

Why do we have a Navigation Act and what were the original intentions of the Act? The Australian Navigation Act came into being in 1912. It was based on the British Merchant Shipping Act of 1894 adapted to Australian conditions. The provisions of the Act underpin almost all aspects of the conduct of Australian merchant shipping. The primary objective was to build up an Australian Mercantile Marine, but in the context of an `even-handed attitude' towards shipping.
This `even-handed attitude' was made quite clear by the Attorney-General of the time (Billy Hughes), when he said:

`The shipping industry must not be treated differently from any other. We have to consider how far our policy can be applied without materially interfering with our commerce and the convenience of our travelling public or without attempting a policy of differential treatment towards the various maritime nations.'

The Navigation Bill was debated from September 1910 until the Bill finally passed both Houses in December 1912. Both Houses were divided on the question of the coasting trade. The arguments for the protection of the coastal trade will be only too familiar:
`It is of vital importance that Australia build up its own Mercantile Marine and thereby have a maritime presence in the Pacific area.'

`Australia has the highest standard of wages and living conditions in the world.' (Remember that this was 1910; we are now fourteenth and dropping in the world list.) `These standards must be maintained at all costs.'
`Foreign vessels in competition with our own are heavily subsidized by their own Governments.'
`Most other countries also protect their coastal trade.'
One other argument may not be so familiar today, although it will evoke memories for many of us:
`Crews operating in the coastal trade should be white and not coloured, because coloured crews were not treated with the same wages and conditions as white crews.'
But there was some sanity in the Parliament at that time and the counter arguments ran as follows:
`Protection of the coastal trade will increase the working cost of shipping around Australia.'

`The community will suffer, because if you increase the expenditure of shipowners, they will have to charge higher rates for passenger fares and the carriage of goods, until the increase comes home to every consumer.'
`Parliamentary interference with the laws of political economy hit back in boomerang fashion upon those responsible for it.'
And to quote more fully from a speech in 1912 by Mr William James McWilliams from Tasmania:

`Personally I regard the Shipping Federation of Australia as the greatest monopoly in Australia; and I believe the whole basis of this Bill is to still further strengthen and buttress that monopoly, and wherever the monopoly does not exist already, to make it a sure and certain chain round the whole Australian coast.'

He went on to forecast that the Shipping Federation and the Labour Unions would make cosy deals between themselves-the former to have an entire monopoly without competition on the Australian coast and the latter to have such rates of pay and wages as they demanded-and the public take the hindmost.
He concluded his speech by saying:

`This Bill strikes at the very root of commerce. It is based on a law which has created, and always will create, monopoly, and which will always hand over the public to two factors-the Shipping Federation and the great organized trades unions. . . By shutting out competition we shall throw the people body and soul into the hands of the Shipping Combine. Under this Bill there will be built up a huge monopoly which will suck the very life blood from the people of Australia who are largely dependent on commerce by sea. We shall be hampering enormously the primary producer by making him pay increased freights and charges.'

Sadly he was absolutely right, and his Cassandra prophecies haunt us today. Although the Navigation Bill passed both Houses in 1912, it was not proclaimed until 1920-and then only in part. Fifty-two clauses and two schedules were proclaimed to come into operation from the 2nd March 1920, but that proclamation was repealed and the Act did not come into full operation until 1921.

Part VI dealing with the Coasting Trade came into force also in 1921, but it was proclaimed in a web of dishonest publicity: it was said that this was legislation which supported competition in the coastal trade. `Any ship-Australian or foreign-could be licensed to engage in the coasting trade provided that it complied with certain conditions.' Certainly, the cost of the licence itself was no bar for a foreign ship. The licence is issued for a nominal fee. In 1981, for instance, a typical licence cost about $5.00.
What, then, was the crippling and unacceptable bar to foreign ships in the coasting trade? It was the set of conditions attached to the licence:
Seamen had to be paid at the current rates of pay operating in Australia;
Ships had to operate with Australian manning levels and Australian conditions and accommodation requirements;
If a library was provided for passengers on board, the seamen had to be permitted to use the library as well.

These conditions still apply today-sixty-four years later-to our cost. Australian coastal shipping has to be operated at Australian award rates, with Australian manning levels and Australian conditions of crew accommodation. Unless these conditions are met a licence will not be issued to a foreign ship to operate in the coastal trade.

As all honourable senators will guess, no foreign ship-owner is mad enough to supply two crews for every ship, or carry almost double the number of crew required to run a ship efficiently, or provide rates of pay and standards of accommodation far above those provided by any other country in the world except Australia, including countries such as Sweden or the Federal Republic of Germany with far higher standards of living than ours. It is no wonder that a library is needed to occupy Australian crews on board, since their duties include almost no ship maintenance or repairs. Australian ships have to spend costly additional time in dockyard hands to do maintenance tasks which are done as a matter of course by the crews of other nations' ships. These are the conditions which have successfully reserved for the last sixty-four years the coastal trade almost exclusively for Australian-owned, Australian-registered or chartered vessels and Australian crews.

There is one exception, as I mentioned earlier, to the licence conditions for the coastal trade in Australia. The requirement for Australian conditions and manning levels can be waived for the issuing of a single voyage permit. The Minister for Transport may issue a single voyage permit when there is no suitable licensed vessel available for the movement of a particular cargo. These permits are fairly rare and most of them have been issued for the movement of LPG.

When Part VI of the Navigation Act was finally ratified in 1921, there was very little competition from other forms of transport, such as road and rail. At that time rail was not used for any purposes other than intrastate, and this situation lasted until World War II; by 1962 a standard gauge made rail a viable option between Victoria and New South Wales.

There was also no competition from road transport - the roads either did not exist, or were not good enough to take heavy traffic safely and quickly between States. After 1954, the Hughes and Vale Decision had the effect of eliminating State taxes on road transport and as the highways were improved road began to be a viable interstate option to shipping.

But in the 1920s there was no competition to the shipping of goods and people between States by sea. Shipowners, at that time, could and did pass the extra costs imposed by the Australian conditions and manning levels in coastal shipping on to the consumers and the users of coastal ships.
By the 1970s there was a general decline in shipping services until now coastal shipping declines further and further every year, while rail and road are conveying more and more goods between States.

What went wrong with Australian coastal shipping? The terms of Part VI of the Navigation Act gave a monopoly to Australian ship- owners (and, de facto, to Australian maritime unions) in the coastal trade of Australia. There was no competition from cheaper overseas shipping.
Shipowners have had little or no control over costs-the unions demanded and, by and large, obtained everything they asked for; they were bought off again and again.
It was the classic case of a union monopoly and it has resulted in the highest cost shipping service in the world.

The cost of labour escalated beyond the means of shipowners and shippers, so when new technology became available in the 1970s onwards, it was too expensive to introduce or was outlawed by the maritime unions. For instance, when the rest of the world was using more efficient drive-on/drive-off ferries, the ANL was, and still is, running vehicle-deck ships which need specialized equipment to straddle vehicles off and on board. The costs of loading and unloading these vehicles has been estimated to be 40% higher than they would otherwise be on some sort of RORO vessel. The Tasmanian Government now owns a RORO vessel, the Abel Tasman, and it will be interesting to compare the cost of loading and unloading this vessel with the other types of ANL vessels, when these figures become available.

Except for the Bass Strait trade and some bulk cargo movements, coastal shipping in Australia is dying. True, BHP has recently ordered three new ships into their service with reduced manning levels, but their shipping costs are still high in comparison with overseas ships if they could be used on similar runs. And BHP has the ability to integrate overseas and coastal shipping to offset some of their high costs; for instance their new ships will be used on the coast for only one leg of a triangular run between Australia and Japan.

Who bears the high cost of Australian coastal shipping? In the beginning, the high cost of Australian coastal shipping was passed on directly to the consumer by the shipowner. Nowadays the costs are borne by the shipowner in part, the shipper in part, but ultimately the cost is borne by the consumer and the taxpayer. The consumer and the taxpayer pay for the higher price of steel from BHP, the higher price of goods which are shipped from State to State, the extra subsidies provided by the Government to shore up the Australian National Line in its present critical financial situation, the cost of industrial disputes, the subsidies paid to Tasmania in the Freight Equalization Scheme, and so on.

I keep harping on the high cost of coastal shipping to the community. Let me give you some examples of these high costs and explain how they might have been avoided. A moment ago I mentioned the carriage of LPG in foreign ships by special permit. Most of those permits were issued to foreign ships carrying LPG on the Tasmanian run. But since 1983, LPG has been carried in an Australian flag carrier with disastrous results for Tasmania.

LPG is handled by three firms in Tasmania: CIG Energy, Boral and Mobil. Early in 1983 Boral began to use an Australian vessel, the Island Gas, as a carrier for LPG on the Tasmanian run. This vessel at 6,033 dwt is larger than the foreign vessels previously used-with a larger crew of 23 as opposed to less than 16 on the foreign vessels used (and of course, two crews a year)-and it is much more expensive to operate.

Because LPG is a bulk cargo, transporting LPG does not qualify for any subsidy under the scheme of equalizing the cost of transport fuels throughout Australia. Since the introduction of the Australian flag ship into the Tasmanian LPG run, the new shipping arrangements have increased the cost of transporting LPG to Hobart by 75%: the cost of this transport has risen from $80 to $140 per tonne, or from 4 cents a litre to 7 cents a litre. And there is no prize for guessing that the consumer pays this added transport cost.

Another example of a higher cost commodity because of coastal shipping costs is iron ore and steel.

The Industries Assistance Commission estimated in 1981, in their draft report on the Iron and Steel Industry, that BHP's coastal shipping operating costs were between $20 million and $25 million higher each year than if BHP had been free to use foreign flag vessels from Japan and even higher each year if they had been free to use foreign flag vessels from Europe, say, Sweden or the German Federal Republic.
The same report revealed that the freight cost per tonne of iron ore shipped from Port Hedland to Japan is about half the cost per tonne of the same ore shipped from Port Hedland to Port Kembla.

Sea transport constitutes about 8% of the total costs of BHP's Steel Division. If these shipping costs could be halved by using an overseas shipping company from Sweden or the German Federal Republic, the total production costs for producing steel by BHP could be reduced by about 4%. Think what that would mean to the cost of Australian steel in this country.
Furthermore the unit cost of steel transported from Port Kembla to Perth is 44% higher than from Japan to Perth. It makes it difficult to want to ``Buy Australian'', no matter how patriotic you are.

The most iniquitous example of an unnecessary high cost is Christmas Island phosphate. Australian shipping has all but wrecked the Christmas Island phosphate trade. The Australian Phosphate Commission ships about 900,000 tonnes per annum of phosphate rock from Christmas Island, Nauru and Townsville to the manufacturing centres. Unfortunately for Christmas Island, it is considered to be part of the coast of Australia, so vessels operating the phosphate trade have to engage Australian crews under Australian wage rates and conditions.

What is the result? An exorbitant addition to the cost of phosphate extraction and transport. In 1983, it was calculated that if foreign ships or Australian ships operating at Scandinavian cost levels were used on the Christmas Island/Australia run, there would have been a cost saving of between $16 and $20 per tonne of phosphate rock.

But it goes further than that. Phosphate rock shipped from Christmas Island to Australia costs $30 per tonne while phosphate rock shipped from Florida in the United States of America to Australia costs only $16 per tonne. And it must make an Australian farmer weep when Christmas Island phosphate can be shipped to New Zealand for about $10 per tonne.

Who pays this double or treble cost for shipping phosphate from one part of Australia to another? The manufacturer, in the first instance, the farmer in the second, and the Australian public in the end. After the costs of manufacture, delivery and spreading the cost of single superphosphate fertilizer to the farmer is $123 for Christmas Island phosphate and $111 a tonne for Florida phosphate.

What is the solution for Christmas Island phosphate? It would regain its competitive edge if it were shipped at world freight rates. At least then it would be able to compete with a world supplier such as Florida.

There is another problem which will have to be considered and dealt with very soon and that is the high cost of loading and unloading at ports in comparison with end-handling for road and rail.

Honourable senators will observe that stevedoring charges are the highest single item in the cost structure of container shipping, and a fairly high item for bulk shipping. You will also observe that there is a container cleaning item which amounts to 2% of costs for container ships. This is just one example of an unnecessarily inflated cost item. It is required that the terminal staff do a rough sweep-out after containers are unloaded; the cost is inflated because the cleaners may go on board on the afternoon of the day on which unloading is completed, but rarely do anything until the following day, thus causing unnecessary delay to the ship in port.

Coastal shipping companies suffer from appallingly low productivity at Australian ports, which have the hard-won but unenviable reputation of being the slowest in the world. It takes two days to load or unload 300 containers in an Australian port - it takes four hours using identical equipment to handle 300 containers in Hong Kong, six hours in Singapore and never longer than one day in a European port. But this is a problem for both our coastal and overseas shipping, and is one we must urgently solve if we are to become competitive in a world which does not owe us a living.

To emphasize the absurdity of our present waterfront solution, if deregulation of the coastal shipping trade were to take place, it might seem to the innocent to be feasible to take advantage of an overseas vessel for backloading empty containers from Sydney to Perth or Sydney to Brisbane at backloading rates instead of sending empty containers around this country by rail. But if a container vessel unloads containers at Sydney and next requires them in Brisbane, it costs $280 per container to reposition the empty container by rail from Sydney to Brisbane. But to carry the same empty containers in one's own ship between Sydney and Brisbane costs $572 per container. Why? Because it costs $236 to load each container back onto the ship at Sydney and another $236 to unload the container at Brisbane. This is an absurd distortion of the economic use of our transport facilities.

It is obvious that coastal shipping is in an appalling state. Something drastic has to happen and it has to happen quickly. So what is the solution for Australian coastal shipping? Most people who are truly concerned about the high cost structure of Australian coastal shipping strongly advocate complete deregulation of coastal shipping, permitting foreign vessels to carry coastal cargoes without the requirements of Australian standards of manning and conditions.
What would be the gains to Australia if Australia adopted an `open seas' policy by which any user of coastal shipping would be free to purchase the services of a shipping operator of their choice?
Let me emphasize that there is no doubt that the gains to all Australians would be enormous.

First, every one agrees that the cost of Australian coastal shipping is extraordinarily high. ANL's coastal services could not possibly survive without subsidies, especially the Tasmanian Freight Equalization subsidy. These subsidies cost Australia $30.3 million in 1984/5.

If coastal shipping were opened up to all comers, it is certain that ANL's general cargo services would have to become rapidly more efficient and less costly to survive. And if overseas shipping picked up these services and performed them at a cheaper rate, the gain to Australia would be the price of the subsidies, which is the only inducement at present for ANL to keep on a general cargo coastal service. The result would be a saving to Australia of at least $30 million per year.

Although there would certainly be cost savings in all areas of coastal shipping in Australia, some savings, such as the saving in subsidy, would be considerable, and others would be less; but all savings add up in the end. For instance, administrative costs might be further reduced in face of competition from overseas ships. Every ANL report indicates that the managerial staff levels are too high, and I have been pleased to notice that there have been strenuous efforts to make some reductions in administrative staff in recent years.

There would also be some saving in fuel costs as Australian ships moved to compete with the more fuel efficient overseas vessels. There is already some progress in Australia towards replacing existing tonnage from the older and less fuel efficient ships to newer, smaller and more efficient ships, but ANL still has a number of the less efficient and therefore more costly ships on the coastal run.

There is also a possiblity of cost savings through greater flexibility in the use of ships, which is likely to occur through competition from overseas ships. For instance, it is possible that Australian coastal ships might adopt the flexibility of the ABC Containerline vessels which carry bulk cargoes and containers in combination. Many bulk carriers operating around the Australian coast at present often operate with certain legs of their voyage in ballast. By the combination system, they could operate bulk on some legs and container on others. This could have enormous potential for Australian overseas trade, because it is eminently suitable for Australian ships to concentrate on bulk cargoes on outward voyages and on containers on inward legs.

But the biggest savings would undoubtedly come in the excessively high cost area in Australian shipping - manning and conditions. There would have to be a speeding up of the present glacially slow progress in crew reductions. Remember that the cost of manning and running an Australian ship is about twice the cost of running a Swedish or a German ship, and remember that Australia runs two complete crews for every one of its ships. The latest estimated cost by the head of ANL for Australian crews is $100,000 per year per crew member. Therefore every crew member saved per year is a saving of $100,000 per year.

Immediate cost savings can be achieved even now on Australian ships if certain services on board ship are radically altered; bedmaking services could be dispensed with, and cafeteria style catering could be introduced without reducing living standards on board ship, and the result would be a saving in the cost of steward services for the crew. In a total crew of between 31 and 37 on an Australian ship, cooks, stewards and crew attendants account for 8 of these crew. If this number were reduced by at least two or three, in line with the number of service crew on a Swedish or a German ship, that would represent a saving of $200,000 or $300,000 per ship per year.

Two things have to be considered in this high cost area of Australian manning. First, existing ships in the Australian fleet, which is the majority of the total Australian fleet, have always operated at historically high levels, dating from the very beginning of the Navigation Act back in 1911. And historically it has proved almost impossible to reduce the crew levels on these ships. I include a Table which will show the crew levels for all Australian ships at the present time.

As honourable senators will observe, the ships marked with an asterisk have had no reduction in crew numbers despite the Crawford recommendations nor the stated aims of Captain Bolitho of the ANL. And remember that even a reduction of one crew member represents a saving of $100,000 per year.

Secondly, there are newer ships being introduced into the Australian coastal run, such as the three new ships for BHP, and these will be manned with smaller crews, roughly 26 for each ship - or that is 52 a year for each ship - and that does represent a reduction of about 6 to 8 crew members for each ship. As shipping tonnage is replaced there is no doubt that there will be some reduction in crew numbers with the result of a considerable cost saving for every ship.

But in both cases of the older ships and the newer ships, there has to be a more radical and drastic reduction overall in organization and, therefore, the number of crews for each ship. Overseas lines, especially the European lines, are moving towards a more complex system of crewing; they are moving away from the craft classification of crew towards a general purpose crew with a complete integration of deck room and engine room ratings, so that each crew member can perform a wider range of tasks. This integrated crew system is close to becoming operational in European ships, and Australia will simply have to move in the same direction to compete adequately with overseas shipping. And there is no doubt that only the presence of overseas shipping in competition in Australia will force shipping management and unions to take the first positive steps towards a new style of crewing in Australia.

Every available report and document dealing with coastal shipping in Australia arrives at one conclusion: `There is no doubt that if cabotage were abandoned in Australia coastal shipping, major savings in the cost of domestic sea transport could be realized'. And the greatest area of savings are to be achieved in manning. I cannot repeat too often, that a saving of one crew member represents a saving of $100,000 per year.

In addition, if any user of coastal shipping were free to purchase the services of a shipping operator of his choice, oil companies would be able to reduce their costs by integrating their Australian vessels into their own overseas fleets and operate them under a foreign flag. As a result, Tasmania could have cheaper LPG as in the years before 1983. Some overseas flag vessels would probably enter the coastal bulk ore trade, and BHP could take advantage of that to reduce their steel costs. It is also possible that some Australian companies would purchase an interest in overseas shipping companies to maintain their own carrying capacity on the coast and reap the benefits of the lower cost overseas carriers.

At last the Australian maritime unions would be forced to do something about a real reduction in manning levels and crew costs. Despite all the rhetoric of the Crawford Report and the Labor Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, there has been no substantial reduction in the number of seamen and the manning costs for each Australian ship since 1980.

Technical changes in ship construction and operation in other parts of the world have produced very large bulk carriers with manning levels of 50% of what they were a few years ago. There is also a variety of new efficient cargo carriers as well as container vessels operating with reduced crews. But what are we doing?

There has been some negotiation between the ANL management and the unions, because the five maritime unions which represent the seagoing 58% of the ANL workforce did agree to reduce ship manning levels by a total of 81 berths across the fleet. But what were the terms of this negotiation? No further manning reductions to take place on current ANL vessels after the reduction of 81. So the Crawford proposals have come to nothing - as I long suspected and have constantly stated here in this Parliament. The unions agreed only to a minimal reduction in crew levels, so that they could stand back and say: `Look, what good fellows we are!'. But after that, it is `hands off' further reductions. So the rest of the world will go on producing efficient ships efficiently run with small and highly productive crews and we will look on with our large crews - and two of them for every ship - and have no hope of competing - and the community will have to go on paying for this incompetence and union greed.

One problem of deregulation is the possibility of entry into the coastal service of Flag of Convenience (FOC) ships. But is that really a problem? By and large the less desirable FOC ships - the so-called `rust buckets' - do not attempt to come to Australian ports, because it is well known that Australia imposes stringent safety regulations on any ship entering Australian ports. In the latest Annual Report of the Department of Transport, 15 instances of sub-standard ships in Australian ports were notified to the International Maritime Organization during 1984/5. Where the deficiencies were serious, the ship's masters were prosecuted: in 1984/5 prosecutions were levelled against ships from Greece, South Korea, Philippines, Panama, Taiwan and Italy. Australian overseas shipping regulations also demand that ships entering Australian ports have crews manned and paid according to minimum ITF rates.

However, flag of convenience or open registry ships form about a third of the world's cargo fleet, and they have proved to be very important in cost reduction; they provide an economic and efficient means of transport through the operation of free markets in charter shipping.
Even the Department of Transport has had to admit the value of FOC shipping services to Australia. In 1981 the Department stated that
`These vessels, which operate on the spot charter market, of necessity offer lower freight rates and in consequence have been an important factor in holding down rates in the bulk trades.'

A very recent Industry Task Force Review of Australia's Overseas Liner Shipping Legislation also reported that `low cost shipping had contributed to providing important competitive advantages to Australian Shippers'.

By far the most important open registries at this time are Liberia, Panama and Cyprus, and others include Somalia, Morocco, Honduras, Costa Rica, Lebanon, San Marino, Haiti, Malta and Sierra Leone. These ships are very important in Australian overseas shipping. For instance in the first half of last year 2,440 ships used Australian ports for the purpose of conveying cargo to and/or from Australia. Of these only 114 were our own Australian ships, but 315 were from Liberia, and 452 were from Panama.

These are the ships which have permitted Australian shippers to have some bargaining leverage in overseas trades. But the unions have made many attempts to bar these and other overseas ships from Australian trades. Already Newcastle is a closed port to FOC vessels, although this is an entirely illegal action taken by unions without the sanction of law.

What will stop the unions from banning other ports to FOC vessels or other overseas vessels conveying coastal trade? Section 45d of the Trade Practices Act is the only piece of legislation which specifically prevents trade unions taking boycotting action against overseas vessels which may in the future choose to take on coastal trade activities in Australia. The Columbus Line from Germany, a highly respected flag line, has been picketed by trade unions over a period of years simply because it is a foreign shipping line, but Section 45D has prevented the unions from actually banning the Columbus ships from entering and leaving Australian ports. And, given a firm government will, the same Act can be used to prevent the selfish denial of shipping services which would benefit the whole community.

For the only possible way to force down the cost of coastal shipping in Australia is to widen the competition to include vessels with a lower cost structure than Australia. There is absolutely no doubt that Australia has the highest cost structure in the world for shipping. The unit cost of transporting coal from Newcastle to Port Hedland would be drastically reduced if the coal were carried in a Japanese ship at Japanese standards of manning and conditions, and the unit cost would be halved if the coal were carried in a Swedish ship, Belgian ship or a German ship at European standards of manning and conditions.

There is no other way to reduce the Australian costs in shipping. All the consensuses, or consultations or Accords that this Government or any other government can ever dream up will never achieve cheaper shipping in Australia. The only way to achieve it is by competition.

Some people will argue that introducing overseas ships into the coastal trade is the same thing as employing cheap labour from a developing nation to drive the buses in Australian cities, or permitting the Koreans to set up a steel works in Australia with cheaper Korean labour and Korean standards of wages and conditions. The analogy is false and misleading. What Australia does do is import a wide range of goods from the Third World, especially Pacific countries, such as textiles, craft works and clothing, reaping the benefit of the cheaper labour content of these goods. By doing so, we introduce competition in Australia for similar goods and the lower price of the imported goods are a benefit to the consumer; these goods are also important because they assist to hedge inflation and increase competition in the domestic economy.

The present coastal shipping situation is economically untenable - bulk goods will continue to be carried around the coast in ships, but other goods will more and more resort to the uneconomic transport facilities provided by road and rail, unless a cheaper form of shipping can be provided on the Australian coast. Non-bulk shipping on the coast will gradually die, to the great loss of the Australian economy.

As Mr McWilliams so correctly predicted in 1912, Part VI of the Navigation Act has become a monster. And it was this Federal Parliament which put this monster into place. This Parliament endowed Australia with a union monopoly which has resulted in the most expensive shipping service in the world.

Even in 1924-just three years after Part VI came into force, there was an urgent public plea for the repeal of Part VI. The Report of the Royal Commission on the Navigation Act in 1924 was quite definite and precise: `the Navigation Act has failed in its purpose to build up an Australian Mercantile Marine'. The Report concluded: `The only recommendation which your Commissioners desire to make is one which will remove most of the grounds for complaint before your Commissioners, and that recommendation is that Part VI (the Coastal Trade) of the Act be repealed'.
With that recommendation I heartily concur. It has long been Liberal Party policy to repeal protective provisions in the Navigation Act.
It is up to this Parliament to undo the damage that it did in 1922.

The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for major reforms to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to better suit the needs of industry. The reforms are consistent with the Government's Policy Statement `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities' released as a white paper on 29 January 1986. They will streamline the operation of the Corporation and make it more cost effective, and they will distribute the cost of funding its operation more evenly across levy payers.

Associated with this Bill are the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill, the Grape Research Levy Bill, Grape Research Levy Collection Bill and the Wine Research (Repeal) Bill. Together these form a package of measures for funding the Corporation, for bringing wine research into line with the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 and thus providing a more stable funding environment, and for establishing grape research arrangements consistent with the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act.

This package of legislation and the decision to establish as a separate entity a non statutory Wine and Grape Industry Advisory Council was developed following some three years of consultations between the Government and the main organisations within the wine and grape industries.

The levy for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation has remained unchanged for 13 years. Some meaningful activity has survived largely because erosion of the real value of the levy by inflation has been partly offset by increased vintages. However, when this Government took office some three years ago certain industry interests expressed concern that the Corporation's funding was totally inadequate for it to be effective but Corporation moves to increase the levy were opposed by large winemakers.

Against this background a committee which included leaders of major national organisations within the wine and grape industries was established to facilitate dis- cussion with the Government on the future of the Corporation and other matters of major importance to the industry.

Not all sectors of the industry support this package in full. Some of the large winemakers with the expertise to carry out their own export promotion etc. are opposed to the existence of the Corporation and object to levies upon them being used to finance such a body. However, other sectors of the industry strongly favour continuation of the Corporation. These winemakers support the concept of general administrative backing for export promotion being funded from levy proceeds, with participation in export promotion being voluntary and on a fee for service basis.

The Government is firmly convinced that continu- ation of the Corporation is in the best long term interests of the industry as a whole. This Bill therefore provides for its continuation but introduces changes which the Government believes constructively address the concerns raised by the larger winemakers.

The decision to legislate for funding grape research follows consideration of an industry request for this. There are some grapegrowers who have expressed opposition to proceeding with grape research at this time. However, they are very much in the minority. The Government believes that an industry-wide commitment to research is essential if the industry's full potential is to be realised. It is therefore fully prepared to play its part and respond to the industry request by providing a funding environment which will serve to achieve this.
All interests favour placing wine research funding on a statutory basis.
The proposals embodied in this and the associated Bills thus follow full consultation with the industry and very careful consideration of all relevant issues.

The Bill provides for the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to undertake a range of functions similar to those embodied in the principal Act. However, as production-oriented research is being catered for under the Rural Industries Research Act, Clause 6 of the Bill provides for deletion of reference to this function.
An important change is the way the Corporation will operate in future and its powers have been revised to reflect this.

The Bill provides the Corporation with maximum flexibility to apply the ``user pays'' principle in financing its operations. Explicitly, Clause 7 empowers the Corporation to charge fees to recover costs associated with the control of exports and for the provision of services including co-ordination export promotion activities. Thus the burden of payment rests on those using the service and the basic cost of funding the Corporation can be minimised. In keeping with the functions envisaged for the Corporation the power of the Corporation itself to buy, sell or otherwise engage in trade in grape products on a commercial basis is removed. This power has not been used by the Corporation.

In the past the Corporation has been the only forum in which representatives from the inter-dependent grape growing and winemaking sectors have met on a regular formalised basis. As a result there has been a tendency for it to be used as a forum for airing issues concerning industry or Government policy and it is arguable that the attention and effort of the Corporation has been diverted from its commercial functions.

The Corporation's role is dealing with commercial activities, essentially associated with export promotion and regulation. The Government believes that the commercial roles of Statutory Marketing Authorities require an approach to the composition and selection of the Corporation Boards quite different to that which has applied in the past. It is not appropriate that the Board comprise persons to represent various sectors of the industry but rather that they have the skills appropriate to their corporate responsibilities.

Clause 9 of the Bill reflects the decision to streamline the Corporation's membership which will be reduced from fourteen to eight. The membership will comprise an independent Chairperson, one Commonwealth Government member and six other members to be selected from a wide spectrum of business on the basis of their professional qualifications and work experience in one or more of the fields of winemaking, grapegrowing, marketing, finance, administration or business management. The term of membership will be for a period of up to three years but members will be eligible for re-appointment.

Part IVA of the Bill provides for the establishment of a Wine and Brandy Corporation Selection Committee to identify and nominate persons for appointment as specially qualified members of the Corporation by the Minister for Primary Industry. The Selection Committee shall comprise a Presiding Member selected by the Minister and other members who will be appointed from nominations put forward by declared winemaker organisations. The industry which provides the levy proceeds for funding the Corporation will thus play a major part in determining who will sit on the Committee.

At this time the relevant organisations are the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers' Association, the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers' Association of Australia and the Australian Winemakers' Forum.
Members of the Selection Committee will not be eligible for appointment to the Corporation for at least 12 months after the time their membership of the Committee ceased.
The Bill contains a number of requirements of the Corporation to increase its accountability to the industry it serves and to Parliament through the Minister.

The main provision to make the Corporation more accountable to industry members is the requirement, covered in part IVB of the Bill, for it to convene an Annual General Meeting of the industry with the first meeting to be held not later than during the year commencing 1 July 1987. The purpose of the Annual General Meeting is to provide an opportunity for eligible winemakers to consider the most recent annual report of the Corporation, receive an address by the Chairperson on the performance of the Corporation during that year, question members of the Corporation concerning any aspect of its activities and debate and vote upon any motion relating to a matter within the responsibilities of the Corporation.

Levy paying winemakers will be eligible to participate in and vote at Annual General Meetings. The method of determining voting rights and procedures for the convening and conduct of Annual General Meetings will be prescribed by regulation following further consultations with industry. The method of determining voting rights will have regard to the amount of levy imposed. This means that those providing the funding of the Corporation will have an appropriate say in its operation.

Other arrangements to ensure that the Corporation carries out its functions in a business like manner and which also provide the basis for its relationship with the Minister are included in the Bill. For example, Division 1 of Part VA provides that the Corporation will be required to prepare Corporate Plans every three, four or five years, as appropriate, which will define the principal objectives of the Corporation and outline its intended strategies. In the development of the Corporate Plan, the Minister for Primary Industry would expect that the Corporation will consult with the industry to ensure that the industry's needs and priorities are taken into account.

Division 2 of Part VA of the Bill provides that the Corporation will be required to develop for each successive period of one year an Operational Plan setting out the particulars of the strategies to be pursued by the Corporation over that period in giving effect to the Corporate Plan.

Both the Corporate Plans and annual Operational Plans are to be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry for agreement. In this way the accountability arrangements focus on the strategies and longer term performance of the Corporation and free it from the need for constant reference to the Minister for detailed approval of each major activity.
While key parts of the Corporation's Corporate Plans may be made widely known to industry, the Corporation may wish to keep certain elements confidential for commercial reasons.

The Bill also brings into place a number of general reforms designed to provide the responsibility and authority necessary for the Corporation to perform its commercial tasks but within a properly accountable framework.

Of significance are the new audit arrangements covered in Clauses 21 and 22 of the Bill. Since the Corporation will now be required to convene annual general meetings of the industry and submit its annual report to those meetings it is appropriate that it be able to give effect to a preference for a company auditor to audit its accounts should it so wish. If the Corporation seeks to use a commercial auditor, the Minister for Primary Industry will be responsible for the appointment of the auditor, subject to the Auditor-General's agreement that the auditor is suitable and the agreement of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Accounts. As well, to protect the public accountability of the Corporation the Government is making complementary amendments to the Audit Act 1901 via the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No 1) 1986. These amendments will allow the Auditor-General to set audit standards, to have access to the working papers and reports of the commercial auditor and to comment on the results of any such audits to the Minister and to Parliament. In addition, the Auditor-General will retain a discretionary power to audit the Corporation's accounts and report to the Minister and Parliament on its financial statements.

The Corporation will continue to be funded by a levy paid by winemakers on products used in winemaking i.e. fresh and dried grapes and grape juice. The basis of the levy will remain unchanged in that all wineries using the fresh grape equivalent of 20 tonnes or more per annum of grapes and/or juice will be required to pay levy. However, the rate of levy is to be varied and a maximum is to apply to the total amount of levy payable by a single levy payer. Spreading the funding of the Corporation more evenly across levy payers puts a greater share of the funding burden upon those who wish it to continue.

The operative rate of levy and the maximum payment within the respective maxima will be set by regulation. Initially, an operative rate of $3 per tonne levy and a maximum payment by any levy payer of $10,000 will apply.

After allowance is made for those amounts previously provided by the Corporation for research, which will now be funded by a separate levy component, the new operative levy will generate around the same level of funding for the Corporation as before i.e. about $500,000 in a normal year. However, for a leaner operation and with the ``fee for service'' approach this amount of funding should be adequate at least initially.

The first collections of the composite levy to fund the Corporation and wine research will not be made until 1987/88. Accordingly, the Bill includes transitional provisions for levy imposed under current arrangements to be applied in appropriate proportions for these purposes in 1986/87.

Restructuring the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation will involve no costs to the Commonwealth. Administrative savings could be expected associated with the Corporation having greater autonomy in its day to day affairs.
These are difficult times for the rural sector. The continuation and reorganisation of the Corporation is part of a total package of measures designed to benefit the industry over the years ahead.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on grapes and grape juice delivered to wineries and to other processing establishments, the proceeds of which will be used to finance research on winegrapes and other processed grapes. Administrative and organisational arrangements for the scheme, including establishment of a Trust Fund and Research Council, will be in accordance with the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. Specifically excluded from the scheme are those dried grapes in respect of which levy is payable under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971.

At present most grape research is carried out by State Departments responsible for agriculture and by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Apart from activity associated with the Dried Vine Fruits Industry, which has in place well established arrangements, funding is ad hoc and research tends to be fragmented.

The decision to establish a statutory research scheme for grapes and thus place funding on a secure long term basis followed a request by the Winegrape Growers Council of Australia, detailed consultation with the industry and widespread support from the industry, including from winemakers involved in grape production.

The levy will be imposed on fresh grapes, dried grapes, and grape juice delivered to a winery or other establishment processing 20 tonnes or more of fresh grapes, or an equivalent amount of dried grapes or grape juice. The levy will apply from 1 July 1986, the beginning of the levy year as defined, and the grower of the leviable goods will be liable for payment of the levy. Grapes grown by a processor for processing in his/her own processing establishment will also be leviable.

Levy will not be payable on grapes delivered to processors who use the equivalent of less than 20 tonnes of fresh grapes per year. It is estimated that only about 1,000 tonnes of grapes, or 0.2 percent of an average vintage, will fall into this exempt category and the collection of such levy would not be cost effective. Levy is not payable on juice crushed from grapes which are leviable.
The Bill provides for a maximum rate of levy of the equivalent of $0.50 per tonne for fresh grapes. This allows flexibility to increase the operative rate if industry so wishes.

Operative rates of levy are to be set by regulations following consideration of recommendations to the Minister for Primary Industry by relevant industry organisations. After thorough consultation the industry agreed that an initial operative rate of $0.30 per tonne should apply. This is to commence on 1 July 1986 and will raise around $150,000 annually on a normal vintage.

Some time will be needed to build up reserves and develop a research program therefore expenditure from the fund and matching contribution from the Commonwealth is likely to be less in the first year than in future years. In 1987-88 Commonwealth Government funds of the order of $100,000 only may be involved.

A Grape and Wine Research Council will be established under the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 to administer grape research funding, as well as wine research funding arrangements which are the subject of a separate Bill. The Council will comprise an independent Chairperson and a Government member to be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry plus seven suitably qualified persons selected by a Selection Committee. The Selection Committee will consist of the core group appointed for all Rural Industry Research Councils plus three members nominated by relevant industry organisations.

A co-ordinated research program operating within a secure funding environment clearly will contribute to the development of a more efficient grape and wine sector better able to meet competition from other wine producing countries. The need for such a scheme was recognised in the April 1985 Report of the Inquiry Into the Grape and Wine Industries and through its commitment to matching industry funding the Government is prepared to play its part in working toward ensuring the future well-being of the grape industry.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1986
The purpose of this Bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy proposed by the Grape Research Levy Bill 1986.
This Bill should be read as one with the Grape Research Levy Bill 1986, and will commence on the same date as that Bill.

To facilitate collection of the levy Clause 6 of this Bill provides for the levy to be paid by the processor on behalf of the grower and for the levy to be recovered from the grower. Levy imposed on leviable goods delivered during a July-June year is due and payable on 30 September in the following year.

The Bill also outlines penalties for non-payment of levy and in relation to the requirement to submit returns. It includes standard provisions concerning the powers of authorised persons and access to premises relevant to the purpose of effective collection of levy.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
WINE GRAPES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to revise the levy arrangements for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and to impose a specific levy on winemakers to provide an industry contribution for financing wine research.

Proceeds from the current Wine Grapes Levy are used to finance the activities of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation which in turn provides an annual ``industry'' contribution for funding research conducted by the Australian Wine Research Institute. Over recent years this industry contribution for funding research has been matched by the Commonwealth on an ad hoc basis.

Amendments to the Wine Grapes Levy Act proposed in this Bill will provide for the levy to comprise two separate components. A marketing amount will continue to finance the activities of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, the operation of which is being reformed as provided for in the accompanying Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. The research amount of the levy will provide the industry contribution for wine research, the funding of which will be placed on a more secure long term basis under the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985.

The levy will continue to be payable on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice used in winemaking. The Bill provides for a maximum rate of $5.00 per tonne for the marketing amount of the levy and a maximum rate of $2.00 per tonne for the research amount. It also provides for the total amount of marketing levy payable by any single levy payer in any year not to exceed a ceiling of $20,000. Operative rates will be fixed by Regulation. Initially the marketing amount and the research amount of the levy will be $3.00 per tonne and $1.30 per tonne respectively and the operative ceiling on marketing levy payable will be $10,000.

The operative rate of the research levy will not be changed without full consultation with declared winemaker organisations and a reasonable degree of industry support. The operative rate of levy and the ceiling on marketing levy payable will not be changed unless the proposed change has first been put by the Corporation for consideration at an annual general meeting of the Industry and there is a reasonable degree of industry support. Prior to the first annual general meeting the Corporation will be required to consult declared winemaker organisations on any proposed levy changes.

The principal centre for the conduct of wine research in Australia is the Australian Wine Research Institute and its funding has been based on an ad hoc arrangement outside the normal statutory rural industry research funding arrangements. The Government fully supports the wine industry's objective of placing funding of the Institute on a secure long term basis so that it can better address the research needs of the industry.

A secure funding environment for wine research will be achieved by prescribing the research amount of the Wine Grapes Levy as a levy for the purposes of the Rural Industries Research Act and establishing pursuant to that Act arrangements for administering wine (and grape) research funding.

Separate Bills within this package of legislation provide for grape industry research funding arrangements. A Grape and Wine Research Trust Fund will be established with separate accounts to receive the proceeds of the research component of the Wine Grapes Levy and the Grape Research Levy.

The Government is prepared to match expenditure of industry money from the fund up to a maximum level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the wine and grape industries. Should industry so wish, and subject to normal budget considerations, this level could be achieved over a period of five years.

A single Grape and Wine Research Council will be established to administer the distribution of funds for both wine and grape research. This is being done with industry support to provide administrative savings and to facilitate co-ordination of research in each of these sectors where appropriate projects are involved.

In addition to an independent Chairperson and a Government member appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry, the Research Council will comprise seven members with appropriate qualifications. These members will be selected by a Selection Committee comprising the core group, which has been appointed for all rural industry research councils, plus three other members nominated by relevant winemaker and grapegrower organisations.

Each component of the levy will be collected under the Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act 1979 which provides for payment in two instalments at the end of September and the end of March in the financial year following that in which liability for levy is incurred. As the amending legislation will become effective on 1 July 1986, the first levy collections will not be made until 1987-88. It is estimated that in that year the cost to the Commonwealth by way of matching contribution to the wine account of the Research Trust Fund will be about $660,000.

It will be necessary to provide for ongoing matching financing of the Australian Wine Research Institute during 1986-87 as current ad hoc arrangements terminate at 30 June this year. Accordingly, provision has been made in the related Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill for an appropriate proportion of the existing Wine Grapes Levy imposed in 1985-86 but which will not be payable until 1986-87, to be deemed to be a research levy for the purpose of the Rural Industry Research Act. This will enable these funds to be paid into the Trust fund and to be matched by the Commonwealth when expended from that fund.

Wine industry representatives have made it clear that the primary purpose of the new funding arrangements should be to secure the financial future of the Australian Wine Research Institute. Accordingly, it is intended that the bulk of the wine research levy proceeds be allocated by the Grape and Wine Research Council to meeting the Institute's research funding needs. At the same time, to the extent that availability of funds permits, other wine research projects could be considered for support from the Fund.

In addition to the ongoing cost to the Commonwealth of matching expenditure of wine research levy proceeds, there will be a one-off cost to the Department of Primary Industry associated with changes which will be necessary to ensure efficient collection of the marketing amount of the modified Wine Grapes Levy. This is estimated in the order of $5,000.

The measures proposed in this Bill will provide the basis for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation in a way that addresses the demands and concerns of industry and will create a stable long term funding environment for wine research which will help the industry to more fully realise its potential.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
WINE RESEARCH REPEAL BILL 1986
The purpose of this bill is to repeal the Wine Research Act 1955 and provide for the disbursement of the moneys standing to the credit of the Wine Research Trust Fund established under that Act.

The associated Bills within this package will bring the funding and administration of wine research within the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act and will establish, for the first time, grape research arrangements consistent with that Act. A new Grape and Wine Research Trust Fund will be set up for this purpose.

A capital sum of $800,000 stands to the credit of the Wine Research Trust Fund. Interest on this amount has been paid in recent years to the Australian Wine Research Institute as a component of a Commonwealth contribution to match industry funding of the Institute.

An extensive history attaches to the origins of the capital sum. Originally it was derived from the proceeds of an excise duty on spirit used in the fortification of wine. The duty was paid into a Wine Export Encouragement Account and used to finance a bounty on wine exported. In 1947 the bounty was discontinued and there remained a surplus in the Encouragement Account of some $2.2 million.

Under the Wine Export Bounty Act of 1947, about $1.2 million was transferred to Consolidated Revenue and the balance of $1 million was placed in the Wine Industry Assistance Account. Under this Act moneys in the trust fund could be expended at any time within ten years for assisting the winemaking industry.

Following a subsequent Tariff Board recommendation, a Government-Industry investigation was conducted into extension of research in the wine industry. This led to the establishment of the Australian Wine Research Institute and the transfer, under the Wine Research Act 1955, of funds in the Wine Industry Assistance Account to the Wine Research Trust Fund established under the 1955 Act. A sum of $200,000 was allocated to the Institute for capital expenditure leaving the present capital sum of $800,000 in the fund.

The Commonwealth has contributed to the financing of wine research conducted at the Wine Research Institute since its inception in 1955. A five year funding plan commenced in 1978-79 and since 1979-80 the Commonwealth has fully matched contributions provided by grants from the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation which itself is funded through a levy paid by winemakers on products used in winemaking. The five year plan ended in 1982-83 and since then matching Commonwealth funding has been provided by the Government on an annual basis.
From 1 July 1986 onwards matching Commonwealth funding for wine research at the Institute will be provided in accordance with the Rural Industries Research Act 1985.

Clause 4 of this Bill provides for an amount of $300,000 to be paid out of the existing Wine Research Trust Fund to the proposed Grape and Wine Research Trust Fund for the purpose of grape research. It also provides for the balance of the moneys in the fund, including any interest, to be paid to the Australian Wine Research Institute.

This apportionment between wine and grape research is approximately proportional to the annual gross values of production for wine and wine grapes respectively. The amount of $300,000, which will not be matched by the Commonwealth, will be equivalent to about one year's match funding for grape research at a levy rate of 30c per tonne, the initial operative rate to apply for grape research.

The direct payment of funds to the Australian Wine Research Institute should help the Institute to meet certain capital and maintenance expenses not eligible to be met by grants from the proposed Grape and Wine Research Trust Fund. This will constitute a one-off Budget outlay. The $300,000 paid into the Grape and Wine Research Trust Fund will be a transfer within the public accounts system.
Clause 5 of this Bill provides for the repeal of the Wine Research Act 1955 on a day to be fixed by Proclamation after the last payment is made from the Wine Research Trust Fund.
The disbursement of funds to both winemakers and grapegrowers as proposed is equitable and will help to establish research under the new arrangements on a firm footing.
I commend this Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee was last dealing with this Bill it was considering clause 22 and an amendment to the clause by Senator Vigor to add a new sub-section to proposed sub-section 52a. The question is: That the words proposed to be added by Senator Vigor's amendment be added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted on the previous day of sitting I was starting to point out some of the problems that can occur in situations where one party in a business transaction is able to exercise cartel or virtual monopoly power over the outcome of that transaction. Basically there is a real danger that a huge imbalance in economic power and resources can be used to unilaterally force quite unconscionable conditions on the weaker of the parties. It is for that reason that I have moved the amendment-to extend the Government's proposal to disallow unconscionable behaviour by sellers of articles so that unconscionable behaviour by purchasers of products is also not allowed under the Trade Practices Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The conditions that can be applied through use of cartel or monopoly power can be totally against the public interest. They can also shore up economic inefficiencies and managerial incompetence in the cartel or monopoly itself. I would like to look at the circumstances that can come about because of this distortion in the market-place. The obvious situation is where a small business contractor is supplying goods or services to a large conglomerate. All of a sudden the rules of the game can be changed after the supplier has put in new equipment to meet the standards and outputs demanded by the purchaser. Unless we have a provision with some teeth to prevent this sort of unconscionable pressure from being applied, the small supplier is completely at the mercy of the giant purchaser. This problem is going to get worse as we have more and more mergers and takeovers in the corporate sector. If unconscionable pressures are to be brought on small suppliers with impunity, small businesses will have to be cut-throat themselves, which will not result in a good or very co-operative business sector within Australia. If small business gets clobbered in this way the nation suffers with it. Small business is where the jobs are created, and where the entrepreneurial spirit in Australia flourishes. It needs a fair go. Usually, it will not be able to engage in protracted litigation with the giant economic interests that are trying to pressurise it. In any case what would be the point if a small supplier wins a case, but cannot market the goods or services as a result? That is what the present situation is.

If we put in a provision about unconscionable purchasing behaviour, we have a proper deterrent to large economic forces being misused or those large corporations misbehaving. They will not want the bad publicity that will come from court appearances which follow the abuse of their market muscle. They will not depend just on the small financial resources of the victim as they do at present. The amendment should eliminate some of the more outrageous practices that are brought to our attention from time to time. It will at least redress the overwhelming imbalance that currently is in the favour of economic might and large corporate muscle.

The same sort of thing that I am talking about happens to farmers. A buying monopoly or cartel can impose fairly tough conditions to start off with. It can get really nasty if it has some troubles of its own. Usually, farmers are quite unable to take the unconscionable behaviour to the courts, maybe because of some type of financial hold the organisation has over them. There just is not the time or the money for that sort of thing when one is scratching to get an income anyway. With the present rural crisis because of high interest rates and extremely low international prices, people really have enough to cope with in farming without a further attack on their living standards. If the Government and the Opposition are honest in their statements of concern about the rural sector they will join in supporting a measure which will enable farmers to deal with unconscionable conduct applied to them, and also to retain some kind of economic viability. In the past we have established a lot of boards and statutory authorities for primary produce partly because of the unscrupulous behaviour of large buying interests that were able to manipulate the producers and squeeze their returns. I believe the boards and statutory authorities are a good thing but there are still large cartels buying from farmers. We cannot continue to set up boards and statutory authorities forever, or at least after the horse has bolted each time.

If we adopt my amendment we will actually have something which will help and be able to prevent unconscionable behaviour because people will not enter into these situations. We can actually do something to stop the problem from emerging. One area in which this will be of major importance is in wine grape buying. More and more small wine grape growers are being forced to sell up to large conglomerates and multinationals at rock bottom prices. The Government has a grape-pull program in order to help them go more quickly. This is happening after the market situation has been manipulated by the giant interests and giant wine makers who are importing wine grape juice into Australia, hence putting unreasonable conditions on our local grape growers. These grape growers are being left no option but to take what is being offered to pull their grapes after suffering the many injustices that the distorted market-place has inflicted upon them. This is the sort of conduct that must appal every reasonable Australian, every Australian who believes in truly free enterprise and a fair go for those with any type of initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendment proposes to insert a new sub-section in proposed new section 52a. As I have indicated, the Opposition is very concerned about the ambit of proposed new section 52a. It represents an altogether new section in the Trade Practices Act. As Senator Gareth Evans has indicated it will be contained in Part V, the consumer protection area, of the Trade Practices Act. It is designed to give consumers another remedy altogether different from the ones they have enjoyed under the existing Trade Practices Act and, indeed, different from those they have been able to enjoy at common law, expect under a statutory provision confined, I think, to New South Wales where the statutory notion of unconscionable conduct was introduced into law some years ago. I am not sure whether it has been adopted in other States, but it certainly is a fairly new remedy. It has not been adopted Australia-wide. Certainly, it goes well beyond the common law and beyond the remedies which have been taken up in Part V, the consumer protection provisions, of the Trade Practices Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal to introduce the notion of unconscionable conduct into the Trade Practices Act is, as I have said, one of the concerns of the Opposition about the whole Act. We see this as a further development of restrictions and burdens being placed on the business community. We see it as including further elements of uncertainty into not altogether unchartered waters but ones which, so far, have not been very well developed by the law. There is an attempt in the proposed new section to give some directions to the court, without limiting the matters to which the court may have regard, in determining whether there has been unconscionable conduct in relation to the supply of goods or services.

Proposed new sub-section 52a (2) states that the court may have regard to a number of factors, including the relevant strengths of the bargaining positions of the parties, whether the consumer was required to comply with conditions that were not reasonably necessary for the protection of the legitimate interests of a cor- poration; whether the consumer was able to understand any documents relating to the supply of goods or services; whether any undue influence or pressure was exerted on or any unfair tactics used against the consumer; and the amount for which and the circumstances under which the consumer could have acquired identical or equivalent goods or services. Those are some signposts that may make this whole exercise and the obligations a little more certain. I suppose there are decisions, albeit under other statutes, which may throw some greater certainty on this whole exercise.

Nevertheless, as I have pointed out, this proposed new sub-section, which is to provide the signposts, also indicates that the court is not being limited in any way as to which factors it may have regard to. Certainly, it is not limited to those five points, set out in the sub-section, to which I have just referred. For all those reasons the Opposition proposes that following the proposed new sub-section 52a (2) there should be another sub-section 52a (2a). I move:
Page 11, clause 22, after proposed new sub-section 52a (2), insert the following sub-section:

``(2a) In determining whether a corporation has engaged in conduct that is, in all the circumstances, unconscionable, the Court shall have regard to the principle of the need for certainty in commercial transactions.''.

I should have mentioned that other sub-sections also give the court some guidance in making decisions. However, they do not emphasise the fact that in commercial transactions-even transactions involving the supply to consumers-there is, I think, an overwhelming and overriding requirement that the law should be reasonably certain. As we are moving into a pretty new area of legal development in respect of this part of the legislation, we think it is desirable that that overriding consideration should be flagged clearly in the legislation itself. It is, as I said, a principle which the courts have tried to follow in the past. It may be that they will do the same again. However, we think that it is as well to point out to them that this is the view of Parliament. Despite the proposed new section, despite the ambit of the redress and the remedy which is available under the proposed new section and despite the various signposts which the Parliament is giving the courts in creating this new remedy, it would be as well to emphasise that overriding principle of certainty in commercial transactions.

It should be noticed that the Bill in its present form abandons the whole method of drafting that was inherent in the original Green Paper proposal whereby numerous factors that were to be considered by the court were spelt out. It reads very oddly in that kind of context and potentially dangerously so far as the likely interpretation of the provision is concerned.

D. Finn, published by the Law Book Co. Ltd in 1985. Referring to a commentary on section 52a by another author, Dr Hardingham, Sir Anthony Mason said:

Dr Hardingham rightly regards the direction to the court in section 52a (2) to `have regard to . . . the weight to be given in the case to the principle of the need for certainty in commercial transactions' as amounting to a little more than a political gesture. One can scarcely describe `the need for certainty in commercial transactions' as a principle, legal or otherwise; and its force as a relevant consideration is as an element to be taken into account, not in the disposition of the particular, but in the shaping of a legal principle giving expression to the concept of unconscionability as it applies to contracts and in delimiting the area of operation of that legal principle.

I hope that Senator Durack will notice the lack of affection and favour with which one of the most distinguished members of the High Court of Australia has regarded the particular language of his amendment and graciously withdraw it or, if not, not yell too loudly in its support when we come to a vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We have looked at this matter and decided that the amendment really does not add anything that we would like to have added to the Act.
