TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 10, line 37, leave out ``section is'', insert ``sections are''.
(3) Page 11, after proposed new section 52A, add the following new section:
``Disclosure of interest
`52B. A corporation acting as an agent in trade or commerce shall disclose to the principal for whom the corporation is acting-
(a) if the corporation is itself a principal in respect of the same transaction-that fact;
(b) if the corporation is also acting for another principal in respect of the same transaction-
(i) that fact; and
(ii) the identity of the other principal or, if the other principal has requested that his or her identity not be disclosed, that fact; and
(c) if the corporation has any interest, direct or indirect, in the transaction, otherwise than in the capacity of agent for the first-mentioned principal-the nature of that interest.'.''

The purpose of these amendments is to require agents to declare their interests as principals in any transaction so that persons employing them as agents are aware of possible conflicts of interest. In the past this practice has led to considerable abuses of trust by agents over a number of years. In South Australia real estate agents have, for a number of years, been banned from having any direct or indirect interest in any transaction in which they have been commissioned to act. Victoria has similar provisions, though not as stringent as in South Australia. This requirement was introduced because of the large number of abuses of trust by agents buying houses at very low prices and then reselling those houses shortly thereafter at a much higher price. Similar abuses of trust are well known in other areas of trade and commerce and, indeed, this is what this amendment seeks to control. For example, stock agents are well known to purchase stock in their own or their company's name without revealing the name of the buyer to the seller, and then to resell the stock to another buyer. In this way stock have been purchased in central New South Wales and then successively traded or exchanged with a commission paid on each transfer and transport paid at each stage until the stock eventually reaches port in South Australia or southern Victoria, totally owned by the agent, and is then exported to the Middle East with the agent again making quite a large profit.

Only the other day we discovered that the stockbroker for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, J. B. Were and Son, had been acting both as stockbroker and principal in buying BHP shares through its investment banking arm, Invia Ltd, while a wholly owned subsidiary of Invia Ltd, Invia Custodian Pty Ltd, had been buying BHP shares as an agent for other parties. In other words, J. B. Were/Invia Ltd had been acting both on BHP's behalf, on its own behalf, and as an agent for buyers of BHP shares through its subsidiary. This all came out because of the Holmes a Court-BHP takeover problem which has been well aired in this Senate. Such dealings bring the whole area of sharebroking into question and, I believe, should be investigated much more thoroughly.

This amendment to the Trade Practices Revision Bill does not ban such dealings, but it does require disclosure of interest in any transaction in which an agent is commissioned to act. Thus the principal is not disadvantaged while no restraint, in fact, is placed upon the commercial activities of the agent himself in his own name or in the name of another principal. The effect of this amendment will be to improve the flow of business by increasing the level of trust. In fact, the high penalties for failure to disclose conflict of interest will make such abuses of trust very unlikely. Where the principal cannot be disclosed for one reason or another, we need to be sure that the transactions we are going to have are, in fact, carried out at arm's length. This means that agents have the choice of disclosing the principal, and thereby revealing a beneficial interest, or not being able to act in that transaction. I believe this is the normal type of procedure which should be required of any agent acting in the market-place.

There are already provisions under common law for remedy when an agent has a fiducial relationship with a principal and is therefore not allowed to put his duty in conflict with his interest. This has been brought to our notice. However, the fact that these types of practices do go on means that there is a need for this type of amendment to the Trade Practices Act.

An agent under common law must not enter into any transaction likely to put his duty in conflict with his interest unless he has first made the fullest disclosure of the exact nature of his interest to his principal. In particular, an agent must not sell his own property to his principal without full disclosure, nor must he buy the principal's property without full disclosure. In a case where the agent is not dealing at arm's length with a principal, the agent must establish that he did furnish to the principal at the time of the transaction all the knowledge he possessed concerning any other transaction he might be involved in. However, in Johnson v. Bones (1970) I NSW 28, where an estate agent purchased land from his principal, it was held that the agent was under no obligation to investigate the true value of the land or to obtain a valuation from a third person. The remedy at common law is that the contract is voidable at the principal's option. In cases where rescission is not possible-for example, where the agent has resold the property to a third party-the principal is entitled to an account of the profits made by the agent, together with interest on those profits and on the amount.

As I indicated before, various approaches have been used in State and Territory law to prohibit real estate and business agents being directly or indirectly interested in the purchase of properties they have been commissioned to sell. In such cases the court may, in addition to any penalty, order the agent to account to his principal for the profits gained from the transaction. This amendment to the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 incorporates some of these provisions into Federal law for those States where these types of provisions are not provided in State laws as they are in my home State.

Proposed new section 52B is essentially a re- statement of the position at common law that I have just described, although it will not affect the application of that common law remedy. A person who breaches the new section will, however, be liable to a penalty of a fine of up to $20,000 in the case of a natural person or $100,000 in the case of a body corporate. This would be so under section 79 of the Act. That would be a considerable deterrent to anybody wishing to enter into this type of behaviour. A provision is included to allow the court to order the agent to account for any profit he has made. It should be noted that where the court makes such an order, it would deprive the principal of his common law option of seeking rescission of the contract.

Some of the lawyers in the Senate might well feel that a case has been made out for the need to regulate this activity but might be of the opinion that section 6 of the Secret Commissions Act 1905 covers already what I am trying to achieve. I would like to spend just a little time pointing out the differences between the rather archaic language of section 6 of the Secret Commissions Act 1905 and what I am putting forward in 1986. I believe that honourable senators will realise that what I am proposing is stronger and much more in the public interest. Section 6 of the Secret Commissions Act 1905 reads:

Any agent who without the full knowledge and consent of the Principal, buys from or sells to himself, or any firm of which he is a partner, or any company of which he is a director, manager, officer or employee, or in which he or any person for whom or on his behalf is a shareholder, any goods for or on behalf of his principal, shall be guilty of an indictable offence;

The penalty in the case of a corporation is $2,000 and in the case of any other person it is two years imprisonment or $1,000 or both. It is not clear on how many occasions this particular section has been used, if it has been used at all. Certainly there are no reported cases under it and it is not clear how a court would interpret this section if it were to be the subject of a case, so I was quite surprised when it was brought to my notice by the Attorney-General's Department.

What I propose brings with it far greater deterrence than is the case with the Secret Commissions Act. In the first place, the Trade Practices Commission, with all the resources at its disposal, would have the function of enforcing this provision. The Trade Practices Act provides for much heavier penalties than can be imposed under the Secret Commissions Act. For instance, as I said before, the maximum penalty of $20,000 for a natural person has to be measured against a maximum of a $1,000 fine and two years imprisonment, and for a corporation the maximum fine of $100,000 has to be measured against the maximum of $2,000 that is provided for in the Secret Commissions Act. I believe that the availability of fines of this magnitude will certainly make those who contemplate not disclosing their interests think again.

There is also the matter of the courts being empowered to order that a convicted person or corporation pay to the principal any profits from the `swindle'. This confiscation of ill-gotten profits is one of the most salutary deterrents to criminal activity of which I am aware. In the case of professional people, reputation is very highly valued. If details of the court action and proceedings are published, including the circumstances of the offence, that publication can certainly diminish the standing of the culprit. I believe that, even with the unequal concentration of media ownership that exists in Australia, major cases would be reported to the general public in some way or another. This would therefore act as a very powerful deterrent to unexactable behaviour from the professional sector where people may be acting as agents. On the other hand, the penalties under the Secret Commissions Act 1905 are no more than a slap on the wrist for any major operator or concern. I am proposing remedies that will really be able to redress the offence.

Another point worth making is that my proposed amendment invokes both the corporations and trade and commerce powers of the Commonwealth. Ever since the decision of the High Court of Australia in the Concrete Pipes case in 1971 the corporations power has been seen as very strong, certainly far wider than the trade and commerce power on which the Secret Commissions Act rests. The corporations power of the Commonwealth will enable my proposed amendment to pick up more situations than can be picked up under the Secret Commissions Act. In other words, I am seeking to close effectively a gap in our current legislation which in practice allows large corporations to engage in highly unethical and illegal activities with impunity and also allows this privilege to small-time crooks. I am also establishing a mechanism for enforcing the legislation, thereby removing a large disadvantage that the ordinary person, be he or she a farmer, small business person or private individual, suffers at the moment. Disadvantaged people will not be forced to stand by mutely and cop abysmal treatment from larger and more powerful economic interests if this amendment is passed.

TALK.START.PARA: — While appreciating the vigour with which Senator Vigor has pursued this cause and while acknowledging, as did the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the other place, that the various matters to which Senator Vigor draws attention need further investigation with a view to possible further changes in the law, the Government at this stage is not prepared to go down this track. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Durack, who is unavoidably absent, and on behalf of the Opposition, I say that the Opposition too will not support Senator Vigor's amendments. To be quite honest, we have some difficulty in understanding their purport. I think we comprehend the concept of disclosure of interest with which the section 52b proposal deals but it seems that understanding what is proposed by the wording of Senator Vigor's amendments is difficult. The wording is lengthy. I say with no disrespect to Senator Vigor that the drafting is convoluted. Perhaps that may be the fault of his drafting assistance more than anything else. SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the aim of the proposal is to force corporations to disclose any agency arrangements that they operate under in trade or commerce or whether they have any interest in the transaction other than as agent, and the nature of that interest. INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be added (Senator Short's amendment) be added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as you have indicated, on 17 April Senator Short moved an amendment to clause 17 of the Trade Practices Revision Bill which would have introduced a new sub-clause (8) in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of sub-section (7), an inference may be drawn from the conduct of a corporation only in the absence of any other reasonable explanation for the conduct.
Sub-section (7), which is there referred to, provides in the Bill as it now stands:

. . . a corporation may be taken to have taken advantage of its power for a purpose referred to in sub-section (1) notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.

During the last debate on Senator Short's amendment I stated that his amendment was unacceptable to the Government. Debate on that amendment was postponed because there seemed to be some agreement emerging in principle as to what was intended, and it was thought possible that an acceptable form of words might be able to be worked out. Discussions have been held since that debate with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. As a result the Government now proposes an amendment to sub-section (7), which I foreshadow, as follows:
Page 7, clause 17, line 21, insert `, after all the evidence has been considered,' after `notwithstanding that'.

The Government, I hasten to add, does not itself see any particular problem with the terms of proposed new section 46 (7). It was intended to enable the court, as I indicated during the previous debate, to balance all the evidence, including evidence of conduct and any explanation of it. Nevertheless, to meet the concerns of honourable senators that somehow that provision was unclear and might enable the court to draw inferences from conduct, or the explanation of conduct, in isolation, without regard to all the relevant evidence, we have introduced those words to remove any basis for doubt.

The explanation for proposed new section 46 (7) is set out in paragraphs 51-55 of the explanatory memorandum, and those paragraphs of the explanatory memorandum are equally applicable to the clause as it is now proposed to be amended by the Government. I mention for the record, because it is important in any subsequent interpretation of this clause, which is a tricky one, that the explanatory memorandum was a considered document and should be read as such. Section 15AB of the Acts Interpretation Act now specifically provides that in interpreting an Act the court may have regard to any material included in:

(e) any Explanatory Memorandum relating to the Bill containing the provision or any other document which was laid before or furnished to the members of either House of Parliament by a Minister before the time when the provision was enacted.

The provision in question is intended only to make it clear that whether a corporation has taken advantage of its power for a particular purpose can be ascertained by inference from conduct or from other relevant circumstances. The reason the provision has been put in there is, as I said during the last debate, that there has been a view around, for better or worse, from the one or two cases in which this section has been run and the way in which the courts then responded to it and certainly in the way litigants have regarded it, that what one needed to get a section 46 action going was some direct evidence, which in practice is exceedingly hard to come by. That is the rationale again for the clause. That rationale is articulated very fully in the paragraphs of the explanatory memorandum to which I have referred. That is the reason why we have proposed the clause, but it is also the reason why we are prepared to clarify it.

Let me just repeat for the record the concerns we have with Senator Short's amendment. Notwithstanding the discussions which have occurred outside the Parliament, I believe he may be keen to pursue it. Senator Short proposed that an inference may be drawn from the conduct of a corporation only in the absence of any other reasonable explanation for the conduct. That is, and remains, unacceptable to the Government because it would simply cut the heart out of section 46. At the very least, it would seriously aggravate the difficulties of proof of corporate purpose which the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills conceded existed. The problem with Senator Short's amendment is that an explanation of conduct only has to be open to the court; it does not have to be the explanation, nor, it would seem to be, even evidence to support that possible explanation. I gave an example last time of how all this might work if Senator Short's amendment were accepted and I do not think there is any need to track back over that. There would be no weighing of the evidence if the Opposition's amendment were adopted, yet weighing the evidence is quintessentially what we want the court to do.

Another matter which needs to be mentioned is the objection of the Law Council of Australia, not least because of the presence at some stage of this debate of a Law Council representative who was very carefully watching over us. The Law Council's objection, which lay behind Senator Short's concerns, as he acknowledged, was that the sub-section in its present form would permit a predatory purpose to be inferred merely from the inevitable consequences of genuinely competitive conduct. For example, profitable but low pricing by efficient competitors which prevents less efficient competitors from entering the markets should not be interpreted as an abuse of market power. That was the Law Council's objection. Again, I make it clear that in the Government's view there is no foundation for that objection. It is answered directly by paragraph 55 of the explanatory memorandum, which states:

On the other hand, a corporation which is able to price its goods very competitively by reason, for example, of economies of scale or the acquisition of new efficient production facilities, would not be inhibited from so doing by reason of the fact that it enjoys a substantial degree of market power. By reflecting in its pricing policy its efficiency it would not, without more, be taking advantage of its market power notwithstanding any effect of its pricing on its competitors.

The Law Council's concern we see as essentially misconceived. It is simply not conceivable that a court would draw inferences of the kind which make this section bite from low pricing which was itself profitable. If a profitable pricing activity is still going on, it is very difficult to see how that can possibly be construed as predatory within the meaning of the operation of the section.

The final point which I take this opportunity to clarify for the record-because it was the subject of some debate last time, initiated by Senator Michael Baume-concerns the reference to `average variable cost' in paragraph 54 of the explanatory memorandum. There might have been some confusion in this respect caused by the inadvertent but erroneous use of the expression `average cost' instead of `average variable cost' in the explanatory memorandum relating to the original Bill, which was cleared up in the rewriting. That was probably the source of the misunderstanding, and I was not aware that there had been that misprint, as it were, until we looked again at this issue in the light of Senator Michael Baume raising it. For the record, let me make clear the point that was being made in paragraph 54 and by me in the debate last time. The object of this paragraph was to resolve a question expressly left open by the court and to make clear that the setting of a particular price was a necessary condition to the operation of section 46. Average variable cost is not low pricing but profitable pricing, as contemplated by the Law Council's example. Samuelson, at page 455 of the sixth edition of his famous text-book, to which many of us have been exposed in other incarnations, said:
When price falls below average variable cost, a rational firm will shut down completely.
The position is made clearer by an extended quotation from the judgment of Chief Justice Bowen in Victorian Egg Marketing Board v. Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd (1978) ATPR, when his Honour said:

I have left open the question whether in the ordinary course a monopolist can engage in predatory price cutting only if the price is below some particular cost, and not where the price that is set, although it may deter competitors, is one which merely does not maximise the monopolist's profit. It may be that where one can infer the requisite purpose from other evidence, price cutting may be predatory in the sense referred to and a `taking advantage' of power derived from the substantial control of a market, notwithstanding that it is not below marginal or average variable cost and does not result in a loss being incurred.

That puts the point in context. What matters, as always, is not that any single criterion is absolutely crucial or determinative, but how things add up on the balance of the evidence. It is in order to ensure that there is a weighing and balancing of all the evidence that bears upon purpose that this clause was put into the Bill in the first place. It is in order to make absolutely clear that such a weighing and balancing exercise must go on that the clause is proposed, for the purposes of clarification, to be further amended as I have foreshadowed.

The loss he suffers then is the loss of maintaining that plant in a closed-down state. That is a very heavy loss. TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 35 as it now stands inserts a new Division 1a in the Trade Practices Act after Division 1 of Part V. It concerns product safety and product information. The Opposition's first amendment relates to proposed new section 65b (1), which provides that the Minister may publish a notice in writing in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette containing a statement that goods of a kind specified in the notice are under investigation to determine whether they may cause injury; or a warning of possible risks involved in the use of goods of that kind. The Opposition will be moving a number of amendments to the rest of Division 1A. I think it is fair to say that fairly speedy action will be required in respect of goods covered by Division 1A, whether in the existing form or in the amended form which the Opposition proposes, which refers to goods alleged to be unsafe, prescribed safety standards which are not being observed, the recall or repair of goods, the condition of goods and so on. As I said, the various steps that are provided for in the rest of Division 1A should be initiated with considerable speed by people who will react to ministerial notice of one kind or another. For example, people could respond to court orders or ministerial applications to the court.

It is certainly desirable in a code of this kind, which seeks redress and protection for the consumer by requiring a declaration to be made that unsafe or dangerous goods be banned or that repairs of one sort or another be carried out, that there be a fair bit of speed on the part of the Minister and those who respond to any notices that may be given. We believe that our amendment will greatly assist this process. People who are expected to respond promptly will be more likely to be able to do so if they are given, at a very early stage, some indication of the problem. Presumably the Minister would not publish in the Gazette that goods of a specified kind are under investigation unless some complaints had been made, some warnings had been given to him or he had been given information of some kind about the goods. It may be that at that stage he would not have a great deal of information to give. A statement which just says that goods are under investigation does not really tell anybody anything that they would need to know. Presumably the person who is supplying the goods and who is under investigation would, as a responsible person, want to know what it was about so that he could take action. People may not be able to identify the complaints. Others may know the reasons for the complaints and a notice in the Gazette may hurry them up and alert them to the need to do something about the problem. However, in many cases they may not know the nature of the complaint.

As I said, the Minister would have some idea as to why the investigation is being carried out. Hopefully, there would be some basis for it. We are simply suggesting by this amendment that he should give an indication of why goods are being investigated and why it is thought they may cause injury. It does not seem to me that the amendment would place any added burden on the Minister to do this. The course proposed by our amendment could be advantageous. It could help to resolve problems at even an earlier stage on a voluntary basis. The Opposition has advanced this amendment for those reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government opposes the amendment which would require the Minister, as Senator Durack says, when publishing a notice warning the public that certain goods are under investigation, to publish a statement of reasons why it is thought the goods will or may cause injury. Either it will be obvious, in which case we will not be advancing the position of the company or the supplier any more, or it is not obvious, in which case the Minister will not be able to put a coherent statement together that will advance anyone's knowledge. So although at first blush it might look an attractive gesture in the direction of better information and less arbitrary governmental behaviour and so on, on any kind of faintly close scrutiny, the rationale, I would suggest, for this amendment disappears.

These amendments do not, in any way, affect the scheme of Division 1a, which is to ensure safety of goods in various ways, either by banning the supply of dangerous or unsafe goods, by putting a permanent ban on goods or by requiring goods to meet a particular product safety standard and making it an offence to supply goods that do not comply with that standard and then to require compulsory recall of products in certain cases. These new provisions are all triggered and enforced by ministerial orders. There is provision for a conference to be held with the Trade Practices Commission before, in most cases a final order would be made; but, nevertheless, the initiation of the process and the final determination of people's rights is entirely one for the Minister, with, as I said, only the intervention of some conference with the Trade Practices Commission and some recommendation to the Minister on the way, so to speak.

There is an enormous increase in ministerial power by the provisions of these new sections. I think it is fair to say that it is most unusual in legislation in this day and age, after more than a decade of development of review of ministerial decisions, of great interest in this subject by many people, and of a bipartisan approach by the parties in this Parliament to the desirability of limiting ministerial discretions and providing for review of ministerial decisions, either on their merits or on legal grounds, to have a return to the fullest type of ministerial discretion, which is unabashed, unashamed, uncontrolled and certainly unreviewed by any process whatever. It astonishes me that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, who is at the table and who is responsible for this Bill, claims to have been one of the leading proponents over this decade of the desirability and the need for review of ministerial discretions in some shape or form.

One of the most obvious and important means of controlling ministerial discretion has been by the Parliament itself and by power of disallowance of regulations or of other ministerial actions. We have gone to great pains in this Senate. Long before the review of ministerial decisions over the last 10 years, this Senate had taken a very live and fruitful interest in limiting ministerial discretions by requiring adequate accountability to the Parliament and the power to disallow such decisions. We can see that in this particular case control of ministerial discretion by the Parliament would not be appropriate. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in a long letter to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, certainly made the point that in these cases parliamentary review would not be appropriate because of the speed with which these matters must be dealt with. Certainly the Opposition accepts that view. We do not see this as an appropriate method of parliamentary control. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was very alert to point out the particular problem that is presented by this new Division. In its report of 4 December last year, it has a section on clause 35 under the heading `Lack of parliamentary scrutiny or review'. The question of whether it ought to be parliamentary was canvassed by the Committee and with the Minister. Having referred to and quoted the long letter from the Attorney-General, the Committee stated:

The Committee thanks the Attorney-General for this response. It concedes that in this case parliamentary review is clearly inappropriate given the way in which it is envisaged that the new provision will operate and it has decided not to pursue its concerns in relation to the adequacy of the proposed review mechanism at this stage. However it is examining submissions which have been made to Senators by the Law Council of Australia and it may make a further Report to the Senate on the Bill.

For some reason or other, that matter seems to have got lost by the Committee in subsequent considerations it made of other aspects of the Bill, and it did not come back to it. But certainly the Law Council of Australia has expressed very grave concern.

I do not know why the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills did not come back to it after the Law Council submissions were available. The Opposition accepts the need for some mechanism to replace this wide ministerial discretion. The amendments we propose are to replace the ministerial discretion with a court order which the Minister would be able to obtain in fairly quick time. Instead of the Minister making the orders and putting them in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette he would, under our proposed amendments, make an application to the court for an order. The court would then consider whether the Minister's order was justified. That would be a mechanism for review of the decision made by the Minister.

The Opposition is aware that in some cases there may be need to be more urgent procedures and that is dealt with in our proposed amendments. Shortening of procedures and elimination of the normal procedures are provided for in one of our amendments to cope with the situation where-as described in our amendment No. 17 at page 11-it appears to the Minister that goods of a particular kind create an imminent risk of death, serious illness or serious injury. The Minister may certify that, and a much shorter procedure would be available to him in a case of that kind.

We believe that these amendments are necessary because of the extraordinary ministerial powers, which are not open to review, apart from a conference with the Trade Practices Commission, that may result in a recommendation to the Minister and which he may ignore. That is a very weak process of review. This whole exercise may have major consequences and may cause a major loss to suppliers which they cannot really challenge effectively. The Attorney-General talked about the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act as being a means of review, but in these cases there would be mainly questions of fact to be determined. Despite the ambit of the ADJR Act, it would seem to be quite inappropriate for the review of ministerial decisions required in these matters, which are, as I said, largely matters of fact. It is really a question of determining whether or not the Minister's decision is appropriate on the facts. There ought be some way that that decision can be challenged. If theses powers remain as they are, great damage could be done to suppliers. If the Minister is wrong, there does not seem to be any redress in such a case.

We believe the appropriate way to ban unsafe goods-it can be done in a speedy way-is to apply to a court for an order. No doubt the courts, with their experience in granting urgent and interim injunctions, will be able to oblige if there is that need in a particular case, but we think the rights of suppliers need to be protected. What we have proposed is an alternative procedure which we believe will not inhibit the Minister if he is right. It will protect the consumer and it will protect the supplier. The present code completely ignores the rights and interests of the suppliers.

The Government is proposing an amendment to new section 65r in the Senate, to clarify that suppliers need only notify the Minister of voluntary recalls of goods where the goods are recalled because they will or may cause injury, that is where they contain some health or safety related defect. As there is no definition of `recall' in the Act, the ordinary meaning of the word applies. The Concise Oxford Dictionary defines `recall' as `summon to return from a place'.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, as is customary from that courteous Committee, thanked the Attorney-General for this response; but two things emerged from it. Firstly, the improvement in this proposed section was one of the very many improvements that the Government incorporated after rushing this Bill through the other place, and I am glad to say that significant improvements have been made. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggested, nonetheless, that the dictionary meaning cited by the Attorney-General is not as clear as is desirable in a provision imposing an obligation enforced by a penal sanction and by a period in the `cooler'. The dictionary meaning would not appear to encompass, for example, the publication of a notice by a motor car or motor bike manufacturer informing persons who may have purchased a particular model of car or bike that there is a potential defect in the machine and that they should see their nearest service agent in order to have it rectified. Nevertheless, such notices are regarded as recalls by the consumer movement.

A similar confusion is apparent in the terms of proposed Division 1a. Notices under new section 65f are referred to as `product recall orders', yet new section 65f (1) appears to draw a distinction between a requirement under paragraph 65f (1) (d) to recall goods and a requirement under paragraph 65f (1) (f) that, for example, the supplier undertake to repair or replace goods. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that in view of the potential uncertainty as to what may constitute a recall, the Committee would continue to draw new section 65r to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. It appears that the Opposition is not making amendments on those grounds. It appears to me to be a matter of some concern. It is a concern which the Law Council raised and it made the point that, in view of the penalties, `recall' should be defined. I would be grateful if the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) could explain to me why that is not happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to respond as best I can to Senator Michael Baume's concern. It is the case that the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee commented that, notwithstanding the Attorney-General's response, it still considers the meaning of `recall' in section 65r as being uncertain. The Government does not agree with that point of view. Section 65r is intended to ensure that the Minister is informed when a supplier voluntarily takes action to recall goods to assist in protecting the public. It is likely that a broad interpretation will be given to section 65r because of its public safety purpose. Where a supplier asks for the return of goods to either the supplier or its servants or agents, this is sufficient to bring section 65r into operation. The Government takes the view that the meaning of the word `recall' is well understood by suppliers.

SPEECH.PARA: The example given by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to which Senator Baume referred-the motor cycle or motor car manufacturer informing owners that they should return the machine to the nearest service agent for repair-is clearly an example of action that would be understood by suppliers to constitute a recall of the goods. Indeed, this form of action often appears in advertisements under the heading `Vehicle recall'. I have some examples of that in my hand at the moment. Fundamentally, this action withdraws from the possession of consumers a good for repair by a servant or agent of the manufacturer. Viewed in that way such action has exactly the same effect as a supplier recalling the goods for repair and would be encompassed by section 65r.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned in some comments I was making earlier with regard to the Opposition's 20 amendments to clause 35 that in fact we had our own amendment on a different matter with regard to this clause. Our amendment involves the application of a sunset clause to those goods which are foods or drinks intended for human consumption. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 28, at the end of clause add the following new section:
`Cessation of Division in respect of foods and drinks

`65u. At the expiration of 2 years after the day on which this Division comes into operation, this Division shall cease to have effect in respect of goods which are foods and drinks intended for human consumption.'.

The intention of this amendment, which effectively inserts a sunset clause on those particular goods, is to give the industry time in which to pressure the States into introducing model food legislation, and in particular into introducing consumer protection legislation in the area of food and drink supply and sale which is uniform and which incorporates all the requirements contained in the Federal trade practices legislation before us. It does not, of course, mean that at the expiration of those two years, if the States have not done what is required of them, foods and beverages intended for human consumption will fall outside the legislation, because it is always within the power of the Parliament to ensure that the provisions continue to apply if the conditions that we are looking for are not met. In fact, I received yesterday a letter from the industry which indicated that following discussions it was in support of a sunset clause in order, it says, to `enable us, in this time, to have incorporated within the Model Food Act similar provisions'. That is, similar provisions to those which would apply to it under the Federal legislation. The letter went on to say that the industry is `unanimous in the view that, if mandatory product recall procedures are to be incorporated in the law, then as far as food and beverage provisions are concerned they properly belong in the food law'. So we would like to see imposed a sunset clause that would force the States to act more speedily than they are showing any inclination to at the moment, and of course, the reserve power would continue to allow the Federal legislation to operate in the event that the States did not act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one could believe that a sunset clause in this respect was genuinely going to result in, firstly, a burst of feverish activity by the States to get their uniform law into shape and, secondly, an enthusiastic burst of capitulation by the food and drink manufacturers to recall provisions in such uniform legislation which they are not awfully impressed with in this legislation here today, one might have some warm and affectionate regard for Senator Haines's amendment. SPEECH.PARA: One of the best ways of summarising the difficulties associated with getting the States to agree on model legislation, whether it is about food or anything else, is a splendid quotation from Mr Justice Michael Kirby which the Food Industry Council of Australia actually put in its paper `A Case for National Food Legislation' in February 1984. The quote is in the following terms:

It is ironic that on the continent of Europe, divided by language, separated by culture and history and ancient enmities, not blessed with a common source, served by utterly different legal institutions and personnel, they can agree on uniform laws on so many varied topics. TALK.START.PARA: —What was that you were saying about the European countries all agreeing?

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for the Democrats to say that, in the event that their aspirations, which they may or may not believe in, for model food legislation are not realised, under those circumstances the trade practices legislation can be further amended in two years time and these provisions can be retained within that particular statute. I simply hope that the Democrats have thought through those risks, because I have no doubt at all that the cynics and opportunists on the other side of the chamber, motivated of course by nothing like the high minded considerations that have moved the Democrats on this occasion, will probably leap at the opportunity to support this amendment as one further way of potentially whittling down the scope of the Trade Practices Act. TALK.START.PARA: —I had not for a moment realised when I suggested two years as the end time for the sunset clause that in fact that may be a stick by which to prevent the Government from calling an early election. Clause 38 (Warranties in relation to the supply of services).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 35, proposed sub-section 74 (3), after paragraph (b), add the following word and paragaph:
``or (c) a contract for or in relation to the provision of services of a professional nature.''.

The Opposition is very concerned about the effect that this amendment will have on section 74 of the principal Act. Section 74 deals with the contract for the supply by a corporation of services to a consumer. Section 74 (3) defines `services' in a specific way. It states:
In this section, `services' means services by way of-
(a) the construction, maintenance, repair, treatment, processing, cleaning or alteration of goods or of fixtures on land;
(b) the alteration of the physical state of land; or
(c) the transportation of goods otherwise than for the purposes of a business, trade, profession or occupation carried on or engaged in by the person for whom the goods are transported.

Therefore, section 74 (3) applies to specific classes of services. The clause we are now considering seeks to change that definition to a general definition of services by substituting the following sub-section:
(3) A reference in this section to services does not include a reference to services . . . under-

(a) a contract for or in relation to the transportation or storage of goods for the purposes of a business, trade, profession . . . carried on . . . by the person for whom the goods are transported . . . ; or
(b) a contract of insurance.'.

This amendment would have the effect of changing the ambit of section 74 very considerably from one which has application only to the specific services I have quoted to one which has general application to services, except for those very narrow exclusions that are contained in this amending clause.

In particular, the wider definition of services will apply to all services provided by professions. The change in the definition of services in the general ambit of section 74 has created very grave and widespread concern among a large number of professional bodies. Indeed, large numbers of professional organisations have no doubt been in touch with all senators and have expressed those concerns. The Australian Council of Professions has supported those concerns. It has asked senators to consider the impact that these changes will have and has invited us to make changes to the Government's legislation.

Clause 38 is causing great concern among professional people because it seeks to omit section 74 (3) and substitute a new sub-section. Section 74 (2), which is not proposed to be amended by clause 38, states:

Where a corporation supplies services to a consumer in the course of a business and the consumer, expressly or by implication, makes known to the corporation any particular purpose for which the services are required or the result that he desires the services to achieve--
for the benefit of Senator Haines, I emphasise the words `the result that he desires the services to achieve' made known by the consumer to the person supplying him-

there is an implied warranty that the services supplied under the contract for the supply of the services and any materials supplied in connexion with those services will be reasonably fit for that purpose or are of such a nature and quality that they might reasonably be expected to achieve that result, except where the circumstances show that the consumer does not rely, or that it is unreasonable for him to rely, on the corporation's skill or judgment.

That exception would be a very narrow one if it applies where the consumer expressly, or by implication, makes known a particular purpose for which the services are required. The question of an implied warranty arises. It is only in very exceptional circumstances that the supplier of the services would be able to avoid the appli- cation of that section. As the Law Council of Australia has pointed out, the onus of proof in establishing that would fall on the supplier of the service. Admittedly, this has got to be a supply of services by a corporation, but, as we know, a large number of professional bodies are now supplying services under the corporate veil. That is particularly the case with engineers, and it is probably so with architects. But a number of other professional bodies are moving and will tend to move in the direction of operating as corporate bodies.

The implied warranty is an old sale of goods type warranty where a purchaser makes known the purpose for which he wants particular goods. If he is then supplied with them after having stated that he wanted them for those particular purposes, there is, under old sale of goods law, an implied warranty that the goods will be fit for the purpose for which they were sought and supplied. But professional services are really not in that category. For a start, the sorts of results that can occur if goods do not fit the particular purpose are likely to be largely related to the value of the goods rather than damages on a much wider scale. Therefore, the damage has some relation to the actual payment to the supplier. But in the case of professional services, the damages that could result from a failure to meet the purpose for which the consumer stated that he wanted them could well be out of all proportion to the fee that is being paid. If one engaged an architect to design a particular building and stated what the purpose was although the fee might be a reasonably modest one, the building might be large, and a failure to meet the purpose for which it was required by the consumer is really quite unrelated to the payment of the fee. That is one major problem with the Government's proposed amendment. Another problem is the fact that it is very difficult to see how it would apply to many types of professional services. What is not understood is that, in effect, what the amendment does in applying this existing provision about an implied warranty that the services will meet the purpose for which the consumer wants them, really is not applicable at all to that situation.

Senator Haines said on another occasion that all sorts of fanciful situations have arisen. Let us take the case of a patient going along to a doctor with a particular malady. Clearly, the services are designed to cure it. A patient, if not expressly, by implication, would make known that that was his or her object in seeking the medical services, and yet there is then an implied warranty that the services supplied will be reasonably fit for that purpose or of such a nature and quality that might reasonably be expected to achieve that result. This seems to be taking the matter much further than the present common law obligation of professional services.

At common law, when a person goes to a professional person, there is the implied obligation on the professional to take due care and exercise reasonable skill having regard to his professional status, knowledge and training. If there is a person of a particularly high standing in a profession who holds himself out to be a specialist, the standard of skill, competence and diligence will be interpreted as being commensurate with that particular speciality that he has as a professional. So a high standard of skill and care is required of professional people. It is understandable and has operated very successfully for a very long time. Insurance cover is being obtained more and more these days by professionals simply to cover themselves, without necessarily any legal obligation to do so, although that is also being considered. However, to import into that relationship this entirely different concept, taken from the old sale of goods concepts, and to impose that new and vastly extended duty on professionals is, we believe, quite unreasonable and unfair and will place them in very great difficulty in getting adequate insurance cover for their new liability.

It is not true that this is simply importing the common law liability. Some honourable senators seem to be under that view. This was expressed in this place by one of the Labor senators, Senator Cooney, earlier in the debate on this legislation. It is going very much closer to a guarantee and to making the professional an insurer of success. Despite the fact that on another occasion in this debate Senator Haines indicated that there had been a great deal of exaggeration on the part of professionals about these things, nevertheless I do ask the Australian Democrats particularly to reconsider what they have said, because a very greatly extended obligation has been placed on professional people by this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it is appropriate at this stage to make a formal and considered statement on behalf of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-perhaps I should say even more formal and considered than usual-to explain the intention of the Government's amendment to section 74, both to reassure those various professional groups that have expressed concern about the possible effect of the amendment and also to provide guidance on the intention of the amendment to the courts should it be necessary for them to refer to the parliamentary debates on this Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 in interpreting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The concerns of the professional groups centre on section 74 (2), which implies a warranty in contracts for the supply of services by a cor- poration or consumer that the services will be reasonably fit to achieve a purpose or result that the consumer expressly or by implication has made known he or she desires the services to achieve. It should be stressed right at the outset that section 74 (2) does not imply any warranty where it is unreasonable for the consumer to rely on the corporation's skill or judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who decides?

—The courts decide. Since 1974 section 74 (2) has applied to services which might broadly be described as non-professional services-for example, those provided by trades people such as carpenters, electricians and plumbers, and other persons such as cleaners, labourers and the like. The amendment would extend the application of section 74 (2) to virtually all services, including professional services, the rationale being that this basic warranty should apply to all situations except where they are compelling reasons to the contrary.

SPEECH.PARA: The professional groups contend that this amendment will have the effect that all professional persons who operate as corporations will be subject to an implied warranty that the services they provide will be fit for any purpose the consumer makes known he or she desires that service to achieve. For example, it has been suggested that surgeons may be under an implied warranty that an operation will cure a patient, or a lawyer that he or she will win a particular case for a client.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been given as examples.

—Of course, and that is why it is necessary to answer them, extravagant as they may appear at first blush. The first point that should be made is that section 74 (2) is based on the warranty of fitness for purpose that has long been implied by the common law in contracts involving the sale of goods. This warranty is also implied by the common law in contracts for the provision of work and materials, including those provided by professionals. This was explained by Lord Justice Scott in Samuels v. Davis (1943) 1 KB 526, a case involving the construction of a denture by a dental surgeon, at page 527:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view it is a matter of legal indifference whether the contract was one for the sale of goods or one of service to do work and supply materials. In either case, the contract must necessarily by reason of the relationship between the parties, and the purpose for which the contract was entered into, import a term that, given reasonable cooperation by the patient, the dentist would achieve reasonable success in his work, or in other words, that he would produce a denture which could be used by the patient for the purpose of eating and talking in the ordinary way.

The second point I should make is that section 74 (2) is not expressed in absolute terms, and whether or not a warranty is implied by section 74 (2) is a question of fact to be determined by the courts after examining all that was said or done in relation to the supply of the services. The application of common sense in determining what was the particular purpose made known or the result the consumer desires the service to achieve is necessary in relation to section 74 (2). Section 74 (2), as I have said, only requires the services to be reasonably fit for that purpose or of such a nature and quality that they might reasonably be expected to achieve that result.

As the Australian Medical Association states in its Press release of 9 April this year, `Human beings and other living things do not behave in a predictable manner', and therefore it is never certain that services provided in this context will achieve a particular result. For example, a doctor's treatment of a patient may or may not achieve the result the patient desires-that he or she be cured-because it is never totally certain that the human body will react to treatment in a particular way. Consumers do not, for example, go to doctors expecting to be cured of the common cold or influenza but rather to have the affects ameliorated. It is then necessary to look at whether the service provided is of such a nature and quality that it might reasonably be expected to achieve that result.

When looking at the nature of section 74 (2), it is important to recognise that there is a continuum of services; that is, there are services where a result can be precisely defined and is absolutely achievable and services where a result may not be easily defined or necessarily achievable or a matter of degree is involved. Further a lawyer is never totally certain of succeeding in a particular action for a client-some more so than others-because of the necessary vicissitudes involved in a trial or hearing. By contrast, it could be argued that it is reasonable for a client to expect a solicitor to draft a valid will or provide a legacy to a particular person. The arguments being levelled against section 74 (2) also fail to recognise that there is a qualification to the implication of a warranty where the circumstances show that the consumer does not rely, or that it is unreasonable for him to rely, on the corporation's skill or judgment. There will be circumstances in relation to the supply of professional services where this qualification will clearly apply.

Leaving aside the Government's view that this amendment will not have the effects contended by the professional groups, the Government could not, let me finally say, support the Opposition amendment because it goes far beyond alleviating the professional groups' perceived problems. The Opposition amendment would exempt professional services from the whole of section 74, not just section 74 (2), which is the one that raises this issue about fitness for purpose as distinct from the more familiar concept of due care and skill. No group has suggested that there should be an exemption from section 74 (1), which, as I have just said, implies a warranty that services will be rendered with due care and skill. The Government has been given no reason why any professional group should be excluded from this sub-section and, in fact, no professional group has expressed concern about the extension of this sub-section to professional services. That does not seem to have inhibited the Opposition, however. Its amendment to the Government's proposal here sweepingly strikes out any question of professional commitment to the obligations in 74 (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not wipe them out because they exist in common law. It is a ridiculous idea.

—There is no reason to resist the application in codified statutory form, I would have thought, if one accepts the concept that the obligation in 74 (1) is as precisely conterminous with that which exists at common law. Section 74 (2) implies a basic warranty that, where a consumer when purchasing services makes known a particular purpose he or she wishes the services to achieve and it is reasonable for the consumer to rely on the supplier's skill or judgment to achieve that result, the services will be reasonably fit for the purpose-no more and no less than that. It is noted, as I have already said, that trades people and others have been subject to this consumer warranty since 1974. The Government considers that, like trades people, professionals should also be subject to this basic warranty and will have little difficulty complying with the standard thus set.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I thought the Government's amendment was bunk before, I am now absolutely convinced that it is utter bunk and dangerous bunk. In this advice we have just heard, which is supposed to be advice under the Acts Interpretation Act to a court, we heard no mention--
—They will laugh their heads off when they read that.
—Exactly. There was no mention of the fact that the basic problem that emerges here is that there is a reverse of the onus of proof. This is the key element.
—You are always hunting that particular snark.

—For the Minister to get up here and have that lengthy discussion of the issue without even mentioning at any stage that there is reverse onus involved strikes me as incredible. For the Minister's benefit, because obviously he has not read the material that has come from people like the Law Council of Australia-after all, it is up front in its proposition-I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: If this amendment is enacted, the onus of proving that the client did not, expressly or by implication, make known to the professional the results which he hoped to achieve, or did not rely on the professional's advice, or that it was unreasonable so to rely, rests on the professional. 29 April 1986
Senator M. Baume
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA
Dear Senator,

On April 22 the President of the Australian Council of Professions wrote to you in respect of the proposed amendment to Section 74 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 contained in Clause 38 of the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 which is to be debated in the Senate very shortly. A copy of Section 74 and Clause 38 are Annexures A and B respectively of this letter.

I am writing this letter to you to set out again the concern of the Law Council of Australia in respect of this proposed amendment. The matter was referred to in our earlier submission of November 18, 1985, a copy of which was forwarded to you on that date. However, the Government appears determined to proceed with the amendment. The further amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats in March 1986 (which would have the effect of exempting architects and engineers from the provisions) does not, in our view, go far enough. It seems to the Law Council essential that the legal effects of the amendment be placed squarely before you.

May I make clear that although lawyers will of course be affected by the legislation, I am not writing to you primarily in the interests of lawyers. The Law Council is concerned on behalf of all persons who practice a profession (``professionals'') that their relationship with their clients will be fundamentally altered to the disadvantage of the client and the community at large.

The existing common law duty applicable to the provision of professional services is the duty to use due care and skill. The duty arises wherever a person carries on a business or profession which involves the provision of services, including the giving of advice, of a kind which calls for special skill and competence. The person who provides such services impliedly represents to the recipient that he possesses that degree of skill and competence and is willing to exercise that degree of diligence which is generally possessed and exercised by persons who carry on the business or profession of providing services of the kind sought. This is the formulation of the duty contained in authorities such as Mutual Life and Citizens' Assurance Co. Ltd v Evatt (1971) AC 793; (1971) 1 All ER 150.

The scope of the duty is therefore defined by the objective standard of skill, competence and diligence which would be exercised by a reasonable person of an equivalent degree of knowledge and expertise. Thus a professional who represents himself as being a specialist in a particular field will be judged by higher standards than an ordinary member of that profession. The specialist will be required to attain the ordinary level of skill, competence and diligence of those who specialise in the same field. The existing common law will not usually imply a warranty that the professional will achieve the result desired by his client. However, in appropriate circumstances, such a warranty may be implied into a contract for the provision of professional services (see, for example, Greaves & Co. (Contractors) Ltd v Baynham Meikle and Partners [1975] 3 All ER 99).

The Law Council considers the common law duty of care and skill presently imposed on a profession is the appropriate one. However, the extension to contracts for the supply of professional services of the statutory warranties contained in Section 74 would place an unreasonable burden on the professional in that the warranties would apply to every contract regardless of the circumstances of the case.

If this amendment is enacted, the onus of proving that the client did not, expressly or by implication, make known to the professional the results which he hoped to achieve, or did not rely on the professional's advice, or that it was unreasonable so to rely, rests on the professional. The Law Council considers this reversal of the onus of proof to be improper, particularly as the Government has failed to explain the mischief at which this amendment is directed, despite several requests from the Law Council. Imposing additional duties on a professional and reversing the onus of proof is also likely to encourage vexatious litigation. The significant increase in the potential liability of the professional to his client will inevitably lead to higher costs to the professional in respect of professional indemnity insurance. The costs associated with defending vexatious litigation and increased professional indemnity insurance will in turn be passed on to the consumers of professional services.

Some of these concerns were raised during the Senate debate on the second reading of the Bill on 14 April 1986. In addressing those concerns, Senator Haines referred to ``the most extraordinary concerns'' raised in various submissions to the Government about the likely effect of the amendment to Section 74. Senator Haines then stated:

``I have not been aware in the past that that, in fact, pertains. Doctors do not guarantee success of a venture or undertaking. Lawyers do not guarantee to get a person off whatever particular charge he is on, they simply undertake to do the best that due care and skill, reasonable care and skill will produce. After all, the question is not whether a patient is successfully treated or whether a person successfully got off his case, but whether the person providing the service has provided a service which is fit for the purpose for which it was undertaken.'' (at page 1703, Senate Hansard dated 14 April 1986).

The Law Council agrees that Senator Haines' statement reflects the existing position at common law. However, the proposed amendment on its face, goes further than this and would imply into contracts for professional services the type of warranties referred to in the second sentence of Senator Haines' statement (see Greaves & Co. (Contractors) Ltd v Baynham Meikle and Partners supra).

The Law Council notes that on 11 February 1986, during the debate on an identical provision in the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985, Senator Cooney stated that the amendment merely restated the common law position and should be interpreted in terms of the overall thrust of the Trade Practices Act 1974, which is to create a proper atmosphere of competition and to give protection for consumers. The Law Council can only assume that Senator Cooney is suggesting that the courts will apply Section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 when interpreting the scope of the amended Section 74. A copy of Section 15ab is Annexure C to this letter. If this is the Senators' meaning, the Law Council deplores the suggestion that Parliament should abrogate its responsibility to make clear and effective laws. In any event, a resort to Section 15ab to clarify the meaning of the proposed amendments places the courts in the role of legislator.

The application of Section 15ab would give little comfort to the professional, as the Government has failed to discuss the purpose of the proposed amendment or to specify the wrong which it hopes to right. There is also some doubt as to whether Section 15ab could be applied to a provision which, like the proposed amendment to Section 74, is neither ambiguous nor obscure on its face. The professional would have to rely on sub-section 15ab (1) (b) (ii), which would place on the professional the onus of convincing the court that the provision was manifestly absurd or unreasonable. Quite apart from the unnecessary litigation required to establish the scope of the proposed amendments, the application of Section 15ab is at the discretion of the court and may require the court to make subjective judgments as to the Parliament's intention. In support of this concern, the Law Council draws the Senate's attention to the remarks made by Mr Justice Franki in the Trade Practices Commission v Thomas National Transport (1985) 58 ALR 423, in relation to the application of Section 15ab:

``I have done the best I can with the Section, which I find extremely difficult to apply, especially in a case like this where at least some counsel are not easily deterred by the time required to argue the point fully.''

The Law Council recommends that the Government does not proceed with the proposed amendment to Section 74. If this recommendation does not have your support, then the Law Council strongly urges you to have the amendment referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to enable the concerns raised in this letter to be further addressed by the Parliament, and the Government to make a clear statement of the mischief to which the amendment is directed.
Yours sincerely,
Philip A. Hawke,
Secretary-General

When the Senate realises that the ACA is controlled and serviced by Professor Wheelwright, no less, of Sydney University, whose main claim to fame is that he lectures in Marxist economics-I believe that is quite remarkable-the nature of this matter becomes clear. The ACA of course publishes Choice magazine--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! A Marxist publication.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying is that modern capitalism is frightfully undemocratic, whether transnational or local. Let's get it clear, the capitalist system is the cause of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —They only have part of a conscience-it's like being partly pregnant.

—I believe that is a good analogy. I am surprised and disappointed in the Australian Democrats in this matter. I am not surprised, however, when I look at the people who have been elected to this place to represent the Australian Democrats, but I think Senator Haines is a reasonable person and I would have thought that she would have been intelligent enough to recognise--
