TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Jessop has just outlined is, of course, a clear indication that the Opposition parties support or oppose something according to the other groups in the community who support or oppose it. In listing that extraordinary group of people whom he sees as supporting this as justification for his opposing it, he has laid his ideology fairly clearly before us. I guess there is no harm in his doing that, but I am not so sure that he has done Senator Durack's argument a great deal of good. The Opposition is resting its case here to a very large extent on the arguments put forward by the Law Council of Australia as if the Council were not only infallible in its judgment, but also as if it represented every single lawyer in Australia, which of course it does not. I would say in its favour that whenever the Law Council has dealt with me it has always made it perfectly clear that its committees do not necessarily, and in fact cannot be expected to, represent the views of all lawyers. As everybody in this chamber probably knows, if one put two lawyers in a room and gave them a single problem they would come up with at least three arguments and take three different positions.

SPEECH.PARA: To cite the Law Council of Australia as being the only body whose opinion is worth following is nonsense. Even if that were so I would ask Senator Durack why he did not accept the Law Council's amendments to the Judiciary Act Amendment Bill. When that was introduced it did all sorts of things in relation to appeals to the High Court. The simple fact is that in this chamber, as in courts or anywhere else, people who are putting an argument will use the cases and the sources which best suit that argument. That is as true of the Opposition citing the Law Council of Australia as it is of the rest of us citing anybody else, or Senator Jessop quoting with some complaint the fact the Choice magazine and various other consumer organisations support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is pure objective reason on this side of the chamber.

—There is a first time for everything, I suppose. The interesting thing about the debate on section 74, of all the debate on the amending clauses in this Bill, is that this one has hit new depths of banality at some points and new heights of hysteria, some of which I mentioned during the second reading debate on the Trades Practices Revision Bill of 14 April and others of which have come to my attention since then. For example, there was the extraordinary statement made by a law firm that if section 74 were to apply to professionals there would be an implied term that the services rendered by them would be done with due care and skill, as if there were something outrageous in that proposition. Today I had a letter from a medical professional organisation which said that it had not yet read the legislation but it sensed that it would cause problems. I am surprised that someone on the Opposition benches has not waved that at us as being a very good reason to oppose this clause which amends section 74.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as various other complaints about the reverse onus of proof are concerned, as I said in an interjection to Senator Evans, not even that bloodhound group on the matter of reverse onus of proof, the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, raised that issue in any way, shape or form in its seventeenth report of 4 December last year. The Committee stopped its concerns at section 65 and did not proceed any further. Presumably since it did not proceed any further, it was not concerned that any reverse onus of proof applied to this. The more outrageous of the claims have been that if this legislation goes through in its present form, any far-fetched result which is desired by a consumer or a client of a lawyer, doctor or professional organisation will somehow have to be met or the provider of the service will find himself faced with litigation. I would have thought that that sort of thing was too ludicrous even to put forward. To hear it expressed in one form of another--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read the section? What about just reading it?

—Senator Durack pointed out himself that the section he finds most offensive applies in the main to corporations. Our amendment picks that up to a certain extent in exempting architects and engineers, although not for the reason that they are corporations. Even in the United States of America, where people have a mania for litigation, the situation does not go as far as suggesting that if a client is not acquitted or a patient is not cured, then the lawyer or the doctor responsible will be up on a charge of some sort or another. If that were the case we would certainly have no oversupply of lawyers or doctors in this country because, as Senator Evans pointed out, in every case that goes to trial at least one lawyer has to lose, and the profession itself would be in severe difficulties, I would have thought. It is simply not something that is likely to happen, and to suggest that it is is rather irresponsible scaremongering. As far as Senator Sheil's argument that this is going to stop doctors experimenting on patients is concerned, I have great difficulty in imagining that he was even serious in suggesting that doctors have been leaping around the place, plunging into patients' bodies with a will, or filling them up with all sorts of new preparations just to see what happens. If he is suggesting that that is what is going on and approves of it, I am glad that he is in this place and not out taking an unprepared community by surprise. I will be speaking to our amendment in due course. Suffice it to say at this time that we will not be supporting the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trying to establish the basis on which Senator Haines dismissed the Law Council of Australia's cogent arguments is at best disappointing. The issues surely are the things that should be concerning her, not whether the Law Council's attitudes are supported 100 per cent by members of the Law Council. It seems to me churlish at best and unintelligent at worst to deal with the Law Council's points in such a way. The fact is that the issues themselves and the manner in which the Law Council so adequately dealt with Senator Haines's earlier nonsense have obviously irritated her to the extent that she seeks to use curious debating tactics to try to diminish the import of what the Law Council has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to another point Senator Haines made about incorporation-and this was one of the reasons for her having architects and engineers-I wonder whether she is aware of the fact that a very large number of medical practitioners are incorporated. I have a letter from the New South Wales Medical Defence Union Ltd, which is a professional indemnity organisation representing some 5,000 medical practitioners in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory who are very concerned about this legislation. Among many points the Medical Defence Union makes which are generally supportive of the Law Council's position-once again I have to say, to fit into Senator Haines's proposition, that perhaps not 100 per cent of the 5,000 medical practitioners involved agree with this, just as, no doubt, not the entire membership of the Australian Consumers Association would even know what sort of tricks that lot get up to-is the following point:

It is now common for medical practitioners to incorporate a company (in accordance with guidelines laid down by the AMA) to carry on a medical practice. Accordingly, the amendment will have a substantial application to the profession as it is practised today.

So let us hear some logical response if we can from Senator Haines about why in this circumstance doctors should be excluded from her particular amendment. The Defence Union also makes the point that what is clear is that a new head of liability is to be created against which medial practitioners will have to insure, and the cost of such insurance will have to be passed on to the public. The letter also states:
The proposed amendment will enable a medical practitioner to be found liable for damages in the absence of any lack of care or skill on his or her part (and in some cases result in strict liability).
It further states:

The amendment could result in an increase in defensive medicine where a medical practitioner avoids a pro- cedure in order to prevent litigation. It could result in practitioners limiting their fields of practice, thereby placing strains on the public health system. It could also lead to a very real reluctance to perform new procedures or techniques.
It continues-and this is what Senator Sheil said:

The entitlement of a patient to damages from a medical practitioner and the correlative liability of such practitioner is presently governed by the law relating to negligence. The patient is entitled to the proper exercise of the relevant care and skill of the practitioner . . . to depart from this criterion, without any available investigation, would be quite wrong.

I mention that to indicate that there is another solid body of professional opinion, and I presume those people are not simply ringing a bell to see whether I salivate. I believe they have a real concern.

It is worth mentioning in passing that this question of fear of action is a practical one, and that quite recently, in October last year, the American Consulting Engineers Council expressed some concern about this matter of widespread escalation of insurance premiums and the unavailability of insurance for manufacturers, small businesses, accountants, doctors, engineers, and other professions which is now beginning in the United States and which the Council says could be solved if the court system returned to a view of tort law based on the concept of fault. The Council made the point that the trend towards liability without fault of proof of caus- ation is based upon emotionalism and the unprincipled willingness to award recoveries against deep pocket defendants. This sort of law encourages that kind of activity, inciting people, particularly through the uncontrolled consumerism that Senator Haines supports. This, as I mentioned before, creates an atmosphere of enthusiastic pursuit of professionals, and this law underlines that trend. I stress again the comment by the American engineers that the trend towards liability without fault or proof of causation is based upon emotionalism in particular-and that emotionalism has been demonstrated here tonight-and the unprincipled willingness to award recoveries against deep pocket defendants.

Let us recognise that in Australia the providers of these services are not people with unlimited deep pockets. The usurers of people in this area will charge rates which will ultimately be forced to be reflected upon the users of those services. This kind of law, by encouraging a much more enthusiastic pursuit of providers of services, in effect without fault, or without proof of causation, seems to me a step in the wrong direction in the interests of everyone, not only of the professionals involved, but particularly of the great bulk of users of these services, who are not vexatious litigants, who are not the pains in the neck who in so many instances are funded by government to pursue honest, decent suppliers of goods and services and who, frankly, take advantage of this excessive move by governments like this one into protecting what is, quite frankly, a fringe element of our society which is adding to the disadvantage, discomfort and cost of the great bulk of users of services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The squalid little burst of McCarthyism that we heard from Senator Jessop a little while ago was just about all we needed to round off the complete intellectual shambles the Opposition has made of its case on this particular clause. There are just a few matters that I think need to be rounded up out of that shambles before this matter is brought to finality. The first point I want to make clear, because it has been a recurring theme of Senator Michael Baume's contributions as well as some others, is that the Government has not put together its position on this by reference to either appeals to authority, or the kind of appeals to the nastiness of the opponents of the clause that we have heard from a couple of speakers tonight. The Law Council of Australia, which has taken a major interest in the progress of this legislation, has made a very large number of submissions on the trade practices amendments going back to the original Green Paper in 1984. A great many of those submissions, proposals and suggestions have been adopted by the Government because each one has been treated on its merits, and many of the proposals put by the Law Council have been thoroughly meritorious.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not to say that everyone has had the same degree of force or acceptability. Certainly, we have found it necessary on balance to reject the Law Council's arguments in relation to this particular clause, not least so far as they bear up on this question of onus of proof. Let my last word on the subject of onus of proof be in response to Senator Michael Baume's suggestion that these clauses were all the product of some social security conspiracy back in 1974. I remind him of a new sub-section in identical terms-section 74b (2), which probably dates from 1978 and which casts exactly the same kind of evidentiary onus, if you like, and gives exactly the same kind of defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mea maxima culpa.

—I cannot hope for a more handsome apology than that from Senator Baume, so the case rests. I refer to another theme of Senator Baume's, one which I think was repeated by Senator Jessop as the foundation for his assertion that this clause was all about Marxist millennium. The objection is that the Government simply has not stated at any point the aims behind this particular clause. Let me finish up by saying something about that. The aims have been clearly stated. The mischief simply is this: The present Act selectively exempts all classes of professionals from duties which are imposed upon suppliers of other kinds of services as well as suppliers of goods and that selective exemption has no rationale and no justification. That is the mischief-that there has been some selective exemption granted to a particular section of the community which does not need nor deserve such exemption.

SPEECH.PARA: All that is being sought here in the extension, in particular of section 74 (2)-it has not been doubted by anyone that the duties in section 74 (1) already exist as a matter of common law-is that a natural and logical addition formulation of duties and responsibilities be extended to professionals in a way that brings them into line with others in the community equally worthy of attention and support from the community and that they should be treated in the same way.

The kinds of warranty we are here talking about, of fitness for purpose in the particular service that is rendered is a duty that is quite appropriately one of universal application. If a concreter were employed to pour foundations for a coastal house to be built on sand but did not render services fit for that particular purpose he would be liable-he ought to be liable-under section 74 (2). Equally, why should not a lawyer be liable if he fails to draft a valid will when he is employed for that particular purpose by a client?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is liable under common law.

—It is quite arguable-certainly it has been argued and clearly established by the courts in relation to architects and engineers-that there is an element of fitness for purpose built into the very concept of due care and skill. That, indeed, makes and meets the point that I want to make. Honour- able senators opposite are not talking about some fundamentally new class of obligation but essentially about another way of describing that same standard professional obligation. It is important that the obligation be expressed not in an absolute way but in a qualified way. It is important that there not be liability without fault or liability without causation, to mention two of the points that Senator Baume raised. There is not liability without fault or liability without causation in the way in which these sections are cast. It is important that professionals not be exposed to liability where it is clear that the consumer does not rely on the alleged warranty in question or where it would be unreasonable for a consumer to so rely. It is important that there be those qualifications and that those qualifications are built into the text and fabric of these provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important not that the services provided by the professional be absolutely and unequivocally in every conceivable sense fit for the purpose but that they be reasonably fit for the purpose identified. It is appropriate that there be that kind of qualification. That kind of qualification is there in the language of this provision as it applies to professionals. It sets standards which are capable of being met by all classes of professionals which arguably amount only to the most marginal extension, if at all, of the common law obligations that professionals already enjoy. They are standards which have been imposed on suppliers of goods all the way back. They are standards that have been applied to the providers of other kinds of non-professional services all the way back. There is a mischief in terms of the universal application of provisions of this kind in legislation of this kind. There is a mischief in saying that professionals are somehow above, beyond or outside the scope of these kinds of reasonable obligations. That is all this clause is about. It ought to be accepted on those terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no wish to prolong this debate and I would not have entered it but for the astonishing statements of Senator Gareth Evans in the early part of his peroration when he carried on about how some group in the community had a selective exemption. He said that the professionals in Australia had this selective exemption from any obligation under the law to practice their profession.
—Not under the law; under the Trade Practices Act.

—I cannot believe that Senator Evans does not know that there are medical boards, dental boards and optometrical boards and that people in these professions are licensed to practise in the community. The people they treat-their patients-have recourse to common law against negligent practice, against carelessness and against professional incompetence in any way at all. To have to go through the business of bringing in this Bill in order to bring professionals under the umbrella of all these other things and put obligations on them is, as Senator Michael Baume said, putting a bonanza in the hands of the lawyers of the community-a bonanza which simply has to be paid for by the community. I come back to the point that got me up. Senator Evans's ignorance on this matter is just astonishing.

—Just to set the record straight, Senator MacGibbon knew perfectly well before he embarked on that schoolboy debating extravaganza that I was not saying that professionals, doctors in particular, are exempt from liability for the services they render. There are, of course, a variety of obligations-Senator MacGibbon has described them-including obligations at common law, which I acknowledge. I was talking simply about exemptions from the liabilities and duties imposed by the Trade Practices Act and how that is indefensible in principle in legislation of this kind which is supposed to be, and should be, of universal application.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Gareth Evans first rose in this debate to reply to my reasons for proposing my amendment, namely, to exempt professional services from the operation of section 74 of the Trade Practices Act, he read out a statement which he said had been prepared by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to be read to the Senate for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act. That statement is supposed to be able to enlighten judges as to what on earth this section will mean in the light of the amendment now proposed to be made to it. All I can say is that it will be more likely to confuse the judges who are foolish enough to resort to it than if they were left to their own devices in trying to make sense of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans is very keen on talking about schoolboy debating and that sort of thing. One bit of schoolboy debating that appeared in that statement was to the effect that the Opposition amendment is deficient because it will exclude the provisions of section 74 (1) from professional services. Section 74 (1) incorporates the ordinary common law principle that there is an implied warranty of skill and care in the supply of services. The exclusion of professional services from this section of the Trade Practices Act will have no effect whatever on the common law liability of exercising skill and care under a contract for service. So right from the beginning of this debate we have had a bit of schoolboy antics from Senator Evans. Senator Evans knows perfectly well that the exclusion of professional services from the Trade Practices Act will make no difference whatever to the obligations that professionals have under the common law and, as Senator MacGibbon said, under the other fairly stringent regulatory provisions of bodies that are established in respect of most professions in the States.

The court, in trying to understand how this provision will apply, will want to know what the omission or mischief is in the existing state of the law which has led the Government to introduce this amendment. I understand from an answer that Senator Evans has just given to Senator Michael Baume that the mischief perceived by the Government was the limited nature of the application of section 74-limited, as I have already indicated, to certain types of services which are set out in section 74 (3). The Minister is saying that the sub-section is quite deficient and that we need to introduce a new amendment to apply to services generally. At least, that would be the logic of his argument. The amendment certainly applies to services but it excludes from its application two types of contracts for services. It is argued that the mischief is that the existing section does not apply to all services. But nor does the amended sub-section apply to all services. Quite considerable categories are excluded in the amended sub-section although not to the extent that they are excluded under the existing one. Proposed new sub-section (3) refers to:

(a) a contract for or in relation to the transportation or storage of goods for the purposes of a business, trade, profession or occupation carried on . . . by the person for whom the goods are transported or stored; or
(b) a contract of insurance.'.

I would have thought that they are two pretty large hunks of exclusions. Yet, Senator Evans's sole justification for this amendment is that the existing mischief is that there are exclusions and whole areas that are not covered by the existing Trade Practices Act.
When one tries to unravel this mystery about why these exclusions are included, one finds that the explanatory memorandum states:

However, a new sub-s. 74 (3) will provide that the section does not apply to contracts for the storage . . . of goods . . . or contracts of insurance. Contracts of insurance are covered by the Insurance Contracts Act 1984 and there is no need for additional regulation in this area.

For heaven's sake, why is there any additional need for the regulation of professional services which are covered, and have been covered very effectively, by the common law? All professions are now covering themselves very extensively in terms of insuring against their liabilities. No professional man these days is under any doubt about what his liabilities are and their extent. Not only has professional indemnity insurance been taken up but medical defence organisations have been established to cope with the extent to which professional people are being sued for breaches of guarantee to exercise reasonable care and skill. In addition, as Senator MacGibbon and I have said, there are very strict provisions in State law. Yet, according to the Attorney-General, insurance contracts are excluded because there is already an Insurance Contracts Act and we do not need the Trade Practices Act in this area. Well, we do not need the Trade Practices Act to cover the regulation of professional services for the reasons that I have already given. The explanatory memorandum goes on to state:

In the area of transportation and storage of goods for the purpose of a business, business parties have well-established insurance arrangements which sometimes involve the limitation of liability in a way contrary to s.74.
In other words, there are appropriate ordinary contractural regulations. The explanatory memorandum continues:
No useful purpose would be served in upsetting these arrangements, and for this reason contracts for the storage and transport of goods . . . have been exempted from the application of this section.

So where is the rationale of the Government? Where is the principle that the Government is following in this area? When really pressed, Senator Evans has been able to give only one reason, namely that the existing section does not cover all services. The Government's own amendment does not cover all services. The Government's own explanatory memorandum for the amendment refers to other forms of regulation, either by State law, common law, common form or industry contractual arrangements. No doubt all of these sorts of things are very good reasons for accepting or not applying the Trade Practices Act.

There are excellent reasons why the Trade Practices Act should not apply to professional services. There are perfectly adequate arrangements to ensure that professional people exercise skill and care and are obliged to compensate those who suffer if they fail to exercise that skill and care. All that the Government's amendment does is raise very great doubts about how that liability is going to apply in the future. I think that, almost certainly the amendment will extend considerably that liability. Senator Evans did not come in here and say: `Well, that is the mischief; we do not think the existing liability of professional people is good enough, we want to extend it'. That was not the rationale he gave. He gave a very specific rationale that was limited to the fact that the existing Act applies only to certain types of services.

In our view the Government has advanced absolutely no reason why the existing obligations on professional people are not working perfectly well. In fact there are very considerable obligations on professional people. Widespread redress is available against professional people for failure to meet those standards. The Government has brought forward no adequate reason why the law is not working perfectly adequately and why it should be extended in the way it is seeking by way of amendment. It is simply another case of this Government wanting to create more problems by creating more legislation. The Government has incredible faith in the belief that it will somehow add to the good of the community if it keeps on legislating and passing more and more laws. We resist that view. That is why we have moved our amendment to exclude professional services from this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points that need reply just to clarify the record. Senator Durack began with a great flourish of triumph saying that I had advanced some schoolboy debating point in arguing that the Opposition was off key not only in seeking to remove the application of section 74 (2) to professionals-the new obligation in respect of warranties of fitness for purpose-but also in going so far as to exclude section 74 (1), the guarantees of due care and skill from professionals. Senator Durack said: `Why should it make any difference to remove section 74 (1) from professionals, because those obligations already exist as a matter of common law?' That is perfectly true, as a matter of common law; there is an obligation of due care and skill. But the big difference between the common law duty, obligation, liability and the statutory duty, obligation, liability is that one can contract out, as a matter of common law, from exposure to that particular liability and one cannot contract out of that same liability or duty under the Trade Practices Act. No professional, no provider of a service, can contract out of a liability under section 74 (1) to provide that service with due skill and care by virtue of section 68 of the Trade Practices Act, which expressly prohibits that. There is no such limitation on what one can do at common law-thus the disclaimers that people are required to sign in all sorts of professional situations and in which they have no option but to sign. That is why it is, among other things, that we have argued that these sorts of obligations in the statute, from which people cannot contract out, are important to apply universally and not selectively.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the only other point I want to deal with in relation to what Senator Durack has said-that is, his claim that the Bill, as it is now drafted, is not, in fact, universal in its application; there is this exemption for transport arrangements between commercial parties and contracts of insurance. There was a very good reason for both those exemptions. The contracts of insurance exemption is founded on the fact that there is an existing framework of statutory liabilities and responsibilities-not common law ones, but statutory ones now-which make unnecessary, and indeed undesirable, the duplication of a statement of rules about liability. So far as the transportation and storage of goods is concerned, consumers are still protected by the operation of this particular statute, which is in this part, after all, a consumer protection provision, not one designed to protect business from each other in ordinary commercial transactions. Provision of transport services and storage services as between business parties are exempt essentially because, as paragraph 153 of the explanatory memorandum puts it:
. . . business parties have well-established insurance arrangements which sometimes involve the limitation of liability in a way contrary to s. 74.

No useful purpose would be serviced in upsetting these existing, real world, practical commercial arrangements. It would not be consumer protection legislation that one would be implementing if one cut across those arrangements; it would be business protection legislation, and that is not what this particular part is about. So there is a well reasoned, thought through approach to all these issues that have been the subject of critical attention tonight. It is not a matter of selective, ad hoc indignation or legislative adventures on the part of the Government; this is a sensibly thought through legislative scheme. It does rectify anomalies to the extent that the professions have been exempt in circumstances which, in principle, they should not have been in the past, and the balance sheet has now evened up appropriately in that respect.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be astonished to know that it is necessary for me again to raise the question of the standard of health services in hospitals in the Australian Capital Territory. We again have the situation that there are strikes in the hospitals, the kitchens are not operating as they ought to, and food is having to be prepared by management staff. The strikes affect in particular, of course, the Jindalee nursing home to which I have referred previously, but it has also resulted in the cancellation once again of elective surgery in our hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: Once upon a time the waiting list for surgery was quite modest. Prior to 1984 it was never more than 500 patients, but now we have 1,127 people waiting for surgery, some of whom would have had surgery tomorrow but who again have been told that it will not go ahead. This means, of course, that many families have their lives and their arrangements disrupted, and they have the anguish of waiting some considerable time before they will have any idea as to when they will be able to go into hospital. I do not think those responsible have much thought at all for the sick who are affected as a consequence of their actions.

I had a letter quite recently, before this event, from the ACT Society for Physically Handicapped Inc. That Society complained about the problems of physically disabled children requiring corrective surgery being, in effect, pushed around and having to wait and the fact that they had to approach a local member to get prompt attention. As the Society said, that is not the way the hospital system should be run. The Society's letter stated that families which have a disabled child are under a great deal of pressure without the additional burden of having to prepare their child for hospital over and over again when surgery is cancelled. Nearly 1,200 people have been awaiting surgery since last October.

When we refer to elective surgery, we are not talking about things that people have done just for fun, we are talking about all those operations which do not come into the category of life threatening. Just think what it means to people with arthritis waiting for hip replacements who have to wait an extra six months or so for that operation-the pain and the inconvenience. For one constituent of mine who, until quite recently at least, had waited six weeks for a hernia operation and who had been off work for six weeks, the problems his family were facing in financial terms were enormous.

It is very hard indeed to find out exactly what the problem is but it comes really under the category of demarcation disputes. The Hospital Employees Federation of Australia says that the ACT Health Authority will not talk with it. In the Canberra Times only last week there was a photograph of members of that union barging in to a meeting of the Authority wanting to discuss matters, but only a day or so before in the news I heard the union say that it was not free for meetings for about three weeks. Tonight on television the Secretary of the union said that the Authority always wanted to talk to them after the decision had been made. ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government views with serious concern the expected significant decline in world wheat prices. The expectations of reduced prices are principally an outcome of provisions of the US Food Security Act 1985 (the US Farm Bill), in particular, the announced reduction of 27% in the loan rate from $3.30 per bushel for the year from 1 June 1985 to $2.40 for the year from 1 June 1986. The reduced level of the loan rate combined with other provisions of the US Farm Bill increases the amount of US wheat for direct sale, thus lowering prices in an over supplied world market.

(2) There is no quick or easy solution to the problem of depressed grain prices. Longer term recovery depends largely on decisions by the US Government and the European Community (EC) which between them account for almost 50 per cent of world export trade in wheat. Production and stock levels have increased significantly in both regions in recent years in response to domestic subsidy programs. World prices will continue to be affected while US and EC producers are insulated from market forces. Of most immediate concern, however, are those elements of US and EC agricultural policies which distort world trade through the subsidisation of exports.

The Government is committed to pressing for urgent and aggressive reform of the EC's Common Agricultural Policy. In this regard, the Government strongly supports the US in its efforts to address the shortcomings of world agricultural trade in the forthcoming multilateral trade negotiations. The Government has serious reservations, however, concerning the US Export Enhancement Program (EEP) in particular, by which the US proposes to counter EC export subsidies. There is a danger that countries like Australia which do not subsidise production or exports will suffer most from US and EC trade subsidies.

The Government's views on agricultural protectionism have been made clear in various international forums and at various times by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade Mr Dawkins and myself. Recently, Mr Dawkins reported to Parliament on a visit to Europe and the US. In regard to the US Farm Bill he conveyed Australia's concerns in discussions with senior US Cabinet Ministers, members of Congress and the Administration, obtaining an encouraging degree of support and understanding for Australia's position. Subsequent amendments to the legislation, which include a reduced level of mandatory funding of EEP, represent some improvement from Australia's viewpoint.

As part of a visit to the US and Europe in April, the Prime Minister has made arrangements to meet with President Reagan, Prime Minister Thatcher and Mr Delors the European Commission President, to discuss agricultural trade issues and implications for Australian agricultural exports.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Were 12 Australian peace marchers recently denied entry to Honduras and El Salvador as members of a peace march through Central America; if so, what was the reason for this denial of entry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Foreign Affairs was advised in October 1985 that 13 Australians would take part in an international peace march from Panama City to Mexico City in December 1985 and January 1986. The marchers left Panama City on 10 December. Following harassment of the marchers by right-wing groups in Costa Rica, and their welcome by the Government of Nicaragua, the governments of Honduras and El Salvador announced in late December that the marchers would be denied entry into both countries. The Honduran Government referred only to ``unspecified problems'' in explaining its decision. The Salvadoran Government was similarly reticent in explaining its action. However, Government officials in both countries were reported to have claimed that the marchers were ``leftists'' on a propaganda march for Nicaragua.

I understand that after failing to enter El Salvador, some of the Australian participants flew from Managua to Guatemala City and then travelled to Mexico City, while others remained in Nicaragua for some time before returning to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the determined policy of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in relation to de facto relationships.
(2) How does this policy affect interpretation of status for immigration purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As a matter of policy genuine heterosexual de facto relationships are treated as if the partners are formally married.

While this policy applies for migration purposes, there is a difference in relation to Change of Status. Section 6a of the Migration Act prohibits the grant of resident status unless the applicant satisfies one of a number of qualifications. One of these (Section 6a (1) (b)) is the spouse of an Australian citizen or resident. De facto spouses cannot qualify for consideration under this Sub-Section. However they qualify for consideration under Sub-Section 6a (1) (e) ``strong compassionate or humanitarian grounds''.

To establish whether the relationship is genuine, de facto spouses are required to demonstrate a current, lasting and exclusive relationship containing elements found in marital relationships such as public recognition of the couple as husband and wife, shared accommodation, income or financial assets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the determined policy of the Department in relation to de facto relationships.
(2) How is this policy implemented in departmental assessment of individual claims for benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Assistance provided under the First Home Owners Scheme is made available by the Department pursuant to the provisions of the First Home Owners Act 1983. The Act provides for identical treatment of legally married persons and persons living together on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married.

The Federal Government also provides funds to the States and the Northern Territory for public housing through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA). The States and Northern Territory use these funds together with their own funds to provide public rental housing and home purchase assistance for low-income earners. The States and Northern Territory are responsible for determining eligibility criteria for obtaining assistance. In determining eligibility criteria, States must have regard to the detailed principles covering the allocation of assistance which are outlined in the 1984 CSHA. One of these principles states that
``housing assistance provided under this agreement will be available to all sections of the community irrespective of age, sex, marital status, race, religion, disability or life situation.''

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment now in a position to supply the information to my questions without notice in the Senate on 17 and 20 February 1986 concerning Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory, and the Gazettal of stage two of the park as part of stage one.

(2) If this information is not yet available, when will the Minister, in view of the potentially major implications of the Gazettal for the future development of tourist facilities and mining within the park, and indeed the considerable effect on the future viability of the Northern Territory, and the development of this particular area of the Territory, be in a position to make the information available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. In accepting the recommendation of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry that a major national park be established in the Alligator Rivers Region, the previous Government accepted that it would need to be proclaimed in stages. Stage 1 of Kakadu National Park was proclaimed on 5 April 1979. When the present Government moved to proclaim Stage 2, technical legal reasons required that it be proclaimed as a separate national park rather than be incorporated in the existing park, as had been the intention all along. Consequently Kakadu (Stage 2) National Park was proclaimed on 28 February 1984.

Subsequent amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, which received Royal Assent on 2 September 1985, enabled Stage 2 to be incorporated into Kakadu National Park. The necessary proclamation was gazetted on 20 December 1985. There was no addition to the area of national park or change in status of the areas concerned.

Amalgamation of the two areas provides administrative advantages, allowing the whole park to be operated under the name `Kakadu National Park' and under one plan of management and achieves the Government's long term intention for the area. Conditions applying to any operations for the recovery of minerals were unchanged by the amalgamation of the two areas.
The article by Errol Simper in the `Australian' of 19 February under the heading `Addition to park locks up $40 bn in minerals' is inaccurate and misleading.

Since the status of the land has remained unchanged by the amalgamation, there was no need to advise Aboriginal owners and the Northern Territory Government formally. There was also no need to seek legal opinion. However, the proposed amalgamation was brought to public notice through the Parliamentary debate when the legislative amendments were considered in both Houses.

No plan of management currently applies to the former Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has advised that a plan of management covering the whole of Kakadu National Park will be released for public comment later this year. The plan is expected to take account of tourism needs including accommodation. The incorporation of Stage 2 in Kakadu National Park does not alter implications for the development of tourist facilities and future mining developments.

The former Stage 2 area is not inscribed on the World Heritage List. At the time that Stage 1 of Kakadu National Park was accepted for inscription on the World Heritage List, the World Heritage Committee noted Australia's intention to proclaim additional areas in the Alligator Rivers Region as part of the National Park. The Committee recommended that such additional areas should also be included in the World Heritage Listing. The possibility of now adding the former Stage 2 area to the List is presently under consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 February 1986 (Hansard, pages 597-8) Senator Haines asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the lack of an answer to an earlier question she asked of Senator Walsh during the second reading debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 on 30 May 1985 in relation to the need for friendly societies that provide ancillary benefits only, to be registered under the National Health Act 1953. Senator Walsh was representing the Minister for Health at the time during my absence.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
I note that in response to a follow-up question on 30 May 1985 (Hansard, page 2883) by Senator Harradine concerning this matter, Senator Walsh provided the following answer:

`Most of the friendly societies are already registered under the National Health Act, but there are a few small ones that are not currently registered. The reason that registration will be required from these very small friendly societies is in order to enforce effectively the community rating principle.'
Accordingly, it was considered that the question raised by Senator Haines had been answered.

I have received representations from friendly societies concerning the possibility of being granted an exemption from the registration requirements of the National Health Act. However, I have been unable to accede to their requests.

Most, if not all, of the benefits being provided by the friendly societies would be identified in the definition of `ancillary health benefit' in sub-section 67 (4) of the Act. Accordingly, any attempt to use the exemption powers contained in the Act would have the effect of excluding a kind of business specifically included in the legislation.

In the circumstances, I do not consider that it would be appropriate to attempt to exclude ancillary benefits, as a kind of business, provided by friendly societies, when all other insurers are subject to the legislation. Apart from the discriminatory connotations that would be attached to such an exemption, it would negate the intention of Parliament.

If the friendly societies in question do not wish to apply for registration, they could negotiate an agency arrangement with an existing registered organisation to provide ancillary benefits coverage for their members. Those members would, if they have private insurance, be covered already with a registered organisation for hospital benefits purposes.

I should add that the main point made by Senator Haines was that friendly societies that provided ancillary benefits on a community rated basis should not need to be registered under the National Health Act. While it is accepted that the main objective of the legislation was to preserve community-rated health insurance it was considered that all organisations that provide health insurance business should be brought under the control of the National Health Act and be on a common footing with all other insurers that conduct such business.
